urn:contentItem:5JCM-1CV1-DXH2-63TX-00000-00American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Auto Summit - Final2016-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexis032316a5920434.734American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc at Bank of America Merrill Lynch Auto Summit - Final

Corporate Participants

* David Dauch

American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings, Inc. - Chairman of the Board and CEO

* Chris May

American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings, Inc. - VP and CFO

Conference Call Participants

* John Murphy

BofA Merrill Lynch - Analyst

Presentation

JOHN MURPHY, ANALYST, BOFA MERRILL LYNCH: Staying on schedule, surprisingly here. Next up we have American Axle -- the largest maker of auto axle and drive train components here in North America, with growth opportunities overseas and in the commercial vehicle market; that's our opinion. It also is directly benefiting from the recovery in North America and the strength in GM trucks for now, and redeploying capital to diversify the business and improve the balance sheet here in the near-term.

Today we are very happy to have David Dauch, Chairman of the Board and CEO; and Chris May, Vice President and CFO. We're going to kick it off and go straight into Q&A here. If anybody in the audience has questions along the way, please certainly let us know.

David, the biggest question that we get from investors right now, not just on American Axle but on the whole industry, is where do you think we are in the cycle? And then also maybe specifically for American Axle, how do you think about the upside potential, particularly on GM trucks with the cycle, and potentially how you prepare and set up for a downturn?

DAVID DAUCH, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD AND CEO, AMERICAN AXLE & MANUFACTURING HOLDINGS, INC.: Well, I mean, I think from a cycle standpoint, we are nearing the top or nearing the peak of a cycle but I don't think it's going to drop any time soon. I think we have a strong year in front of us with respect to volumes not only here in North America but globally around the world as well. I think next year sets up -- it sets itself up to be another strong year with consumer confidence being where it is, with pent-up vehicle demand still out there, the average age of the vehicle being 11, 11.5 years of age at this point in time.

Clearly, the market is now saying, with fuel prices where they are, that trucks, SUVs, crossover vehicles and luxury passenger cars are what's popular and in demand right now. And that's right in the heart of our sweet spot as it relates to products we produce.

And then with respect to the second half of your question with regards to GM and their capacity, I mean, we've said all along their straight-time capacity is 1.2 million units. They ran at a clip of a little bit over 1.235 million units last year. They are running at that clip or even higher. IHS has moved it up to 1.265 million. So, we've also said that they have a flex capacity growth up to 1.4 million units, and we have the capacity in place to support that as well. So, if they schedule it, we will be able to build it. And we are prepared to support that.

JOHN MURPHY: And on the downside, which we don't think is happening any time soon, but I mean, if you were to think about sort of a standard 20%, 25% downturn that would occur over about a five-year period, I mean, how do you think you would react to that in the North American business at this point?

DAVID DAUCH: Well, I mean, we've demonstrated our discipline back in 2008, 2009, when we went through the soup with everybody else, but we also demonstrated discipline from 2010 all the way through where we are today. And if the market should turn -- whether it's 10%, 20% or 30%, we are prepared to manage in that situation.

The big thing that we've done is we've really made a lot of our cost structure variable over the last several years, so we can take things out and adjust things to the new market demand if that demand happens to be lower or, in other cases, if it happens to increase. But we're prepared to support any downturn that may take place. And we've got a proven management team that's still in place that managed during the tough times and we will manage -- you know, we're managing through the good times right now. And if it goes the other way because of the cycle, then we will manage that accordingly.

CHRIS MAY, VP AND CFO, AMERICAN AXLE & MANUFACTURING HOLDINGS, INC.: And we continue to work away at our fixed cross structure. Our interest is down 20% over the past couple of years, is another element. And I would also point your attention -- look at Brazil for example -- half the size of it was for us just a couple of years ago. And we continue to run profitable in our Brazilian operation. So we can accommodate these markets. We can flex our cost structure, as David mentioned, to deal with whoever faces our direction.

DAVID DAUCH: I mean, I think that's really been the strength of our organization, has been our operational excellence, and our ability to manage from a conservative standpoint financially but with discipline, and make sure that we don't put ourselves in harm's way. And even when we got in a tough situation, we avoided bankruptcy and we managed our way through that.

JOHN MURPHY: And if you think about some of the stuff that's going on at GM specifically right now on the truck side, near-term, the inventory is fairly tight and arguably maybe too tight. Their logic is to remain fairly lean, so, God forbid, we actually go into a downturn very quickly. They're set up so they don't need to cut production dramatically.

What are you seeing from your side sort of in the channel? And how do you think about this truck inventory and the production schedules relative to sales? I mean, it just seems like they are running the business very conservatively and tightly right now. I mean, what are you seeing from your standpoint?

DAVID DAUCH: Well, I mean I think part of it is just the value chain that they are managing as well. Right? They've got -- like I said, the straight-time and the flex capacity in place at their facility. The question is, does the full supply base have that in place? We certainly do. But I think there may be some restrictions that they are managing their way through, which has maybe limited them in some cases.

They are also being very disciplined in regards to transactional prices and what they are going after. And clearly, supply and demand plays into that case. They've been disciplined with regards to the incentives. So I actually like how GM is managing their truck platform at this point in time.

JOHN MURPHY: Great. And if we think about the diversification of business which is key to -- well, we think is key to the long-term success, I think you guys are onboard with that. I mean, where do you think you are in diversification away from GM? And then also diversification in segmentation? Because crossovers are clearly exploding here in North America but also in China, and probably will be around the world. And you know, sort of how you play in that product set, having opportunities that help with diversification?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. Just starting first with the customer diversification, when we started the business in 1994, GM was 98.5% of our business and we were doing $1.4 billion in sales. Today, we're doing -- we've guided $4 billion in sales. And last year, GM represented, what, 60 --?

CHRIS MAY: 66%.

DAVID DAUCH: -- 66% of our business. If you factor in our joint venture, which is not a consolidated joint venture, it's 63%. And based on our book business, I mean, 60% of our backlog of new business today is non-GM business. We are going to see further concentricity reduction with GM while protecting our business with GM that way.

And our goal is, we see them in the 50% or less range in that 2018 -- 2020 period of time. And that doesn't contemplate anything that we might do from a strategic activity going forward.

JOHN MURPHY: Got it. And if you look at China, right, and the growth in China particularly on the crossover side -- and I want to get back to crossovers as well -- I mean, how do you see the business growing in China in the near-term on the commercial vehicle side, because you have a lot of efforts going on there? Then also with -- on the light vehicle side?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. You know, first, starting on the commercial vehicle side, we put a joint venture together with a firm by the name of JC -- they are a large truck manufacturer in China. We've seen that business double since we put that joint venture into place. And quite honestly, we see positive growth for that moving forward in the future as well on the truck side, as far as the medium and the heavier truck applications.

So that was a great partnership arrangement for us, and we are running that and managing it effectively. They are very pleased we've expanded that joint venture, which has been very positive for both organizations.

On the light side of things, I mean, we really hit the sweet spot with where we are with the luxury passenger car. We are making all the C/D class axles for Mercedes in China today. That just continues to boom and escalate; new capacity programs going in to support that. We are also doing a significant amount of crossover vehicle work over there, because five-seat and seven-seat vehicle applications are exploding in China right now in a positive way, which we are right, again, in the sweet spot.

So, we have incremental capacity that we are actually putting in place to support the growth that's not only there today, but also what was forecasted in the future. So, we see crossovers, not only just in China but globally around the world, as being a big market and a big segment for us to support.

JOHN MURPHY: And can you talk a little bit -- just a little bit about the technology on crossovers? Because I think a lot of people think about American Axle as axles and driveshafts. I mean, can you just talk a little bit about the technology and the solutions you are bringing to all-wheel-drive on crossovers?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. We've got a plethora of product opportunities within the all-wheel-drive category. We have the conventional all-wheel-drive capability that's there. Unfortunately, the conventional all-wheel-drive capability adds mass and has degradation of fuel economy in that category.

And that's why I instructed the organization that I wanted a new technology that was leapfrogged to our competition; we came up with the disconnecting all-wheel-drive, which we call EcoTrac in the marketplace. We were the first ones to bring that to market.

It's much lighter than the conventional system. At the same time, the disconnected all-wheel-drive system allows the system to disengage when it's not needed and engage where the driver doesn't have to do anything. It does it because of our proprietary software controls capability. And you can get back about two-thirds to three-quarters of the fuel economy reduction that you would see because of the parasitic losses that exists with the conventional system.

We are actually working on Gen 2 designs for the popular EcoTrac today that will allow us to get 90% -- the 90-plus-percent back of that fuel economy loss. So, that's positive. And that's why you are seeing a tremendous shift in the marketplace towards disconnecting all-wheel-drives over conventional all-wheel-drive systems.

The other big thing that we're working on, the next generation of product beyond that, is all of our e-AAM activity, which is the hybridization and electrification of the E differential, but also the system in its entirety. And we just finished winter testing in our Northern Michigan facility as well as over in Sweden. We have a whole host of customers over there; rave reviews for our technology ranging from high-end luxury OEMs to international-based emerging market-type countries that are interested in electrification.

And our product portfolio is performing very well. So, we are now starting to see a lot more activity in regards to the quotation activity. Again, with where government regulation is with CAFE and CO2 emissions, each of the OEMs are going to have to elevate their game from a fuel economy standpoint. And I'm clear -- it's very clear to me that electrification is a part -- a growing part of their strategy as we move forward.

CHRIS MAY: And you clearly see the power of that in our topline revenue today, as well as in our backlog. For example, on the EcoTrac that David mentioned, zero dollars of revenue for us just a couple of years ago. When we complete our launch of our backlog, by 2018, it will be $600 million of revenue. So, it's a very powerful technology we've been able to leverage in the marketplace.

JOHN MURPHY: David, you guys have always been a top-quality producer. As OEMs feel more pressure to lightweight their vehicles, get better fuel economy, are there different materials that you guys have investigated to use for your product? I mean, aluminum being one of them; I know you guys have entry into that. Just give us some color like what the future could look like for some of the lightweighting options.

DAVID DAUCH: Yes, certainly. I mean, clearly, we are working with the current steel producers today to come up with various grades of material that still give us the PowerDense capabilities that we look for, but in a lighter capacity. So I'll start with some of the current materials that are available to us today.

Aluminum is already a big part of the marketplace today and only a growing part of the marketplace in the future. Many of our passenger car and our crossover vehicle applications, I'd say the majority -- 90-plus-percent are already aluminum-based. Our front axles for our truck applications, most of them are aluminum-based, although we do have some cast iron. The majority of our beam axle business, however, is still cast iron.

And we have made aluminum axles in the past. Based on customer requirements, we have the know-how, the capability, the NVH performance; we are probably the leader in that category. It's just a matter of what are the customer needs and the specific needs, and what are they willing to pay. Because aluminum tends to be a little bit more expensive than the cast iron.

But again, there's significant weight advantages, so it depends on if the vehicle has a weight issue or not, and then what type of credits are associated with that as it relates to cost per pound savings that are realized. But -- so we're doing a lot not only in the aluminum side; we are actually vertically integrated, in some cases, and are looking to possibly do more in that respect.

We have supplier partners around the world on the aluminum side. What it really allows us to do is design a smaller axle, a smaller power takeoff unit, smaller vehicle in a PowerDensity standpoint that still delivers the horsepower and the torque that the vehicle needs and the OEMs are asking for. So it -- we feel we are on the cutting edge in regards to some of the materials management things as well as lubricity, friction, parasitic losses, bearing applications, to allow us to still provide industry-leading product when it comes to fuel efficiency and lightweight.

JOHN MURPHY: That's helpful. Thank you. As far as the diversification, there's another way to get there other than organically, and it's to do either an acquisition or M&A or combination in some form. I mean, how are you guys thinking about that and exploring that, thinking about sort of the context of the balance sheet and the context of the business?

There's an idea that, even though your stock is wildly depressed and totally undervalued, at least in our opinion, that using stock would be a tough thing to do right now. But if you are going after another company that might -- or combining with another company that might be equally as depressed, there might be an opportunity to do a stock deal. I mean, just how do you sort of strategically think about this? And from a balance sheet, how do you kind of finagle it at this point?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes, let me first just come back to the priorities that we've really set from a capital-U standpoint going forward and just to level-set for everybody in the room, is our first priority was organic growth. We've demonstrated an ability to do that in a profitable way for the last 20 years, but especially the last five years.

The other was debt management. We clearly improved our leverage situation. We are under 2 times levered; we finished at 1.9 at the end of last year. We are still very focused on improving our balance sheet, strengthening our balance sheet going forward. Historically, we ran our business in that 1.5 times range for the most part, so we are still desirous of trying to get to that level.

But now, to your point, with our balance sheet being where it is, with our liquidity being where it is, with our operations performing the way they are, with the cash being generated from that business, it now opens up the opportunity for us to look at strategic activities and also look at shareholder-friendly activities.

So, we are going to balance those four things with respect to what we are trying to do and the use of our cash flow going forward. From a strategic standpoint, clearly we are active in that area before that playbook was closed for us. We're looking at what can we do there, especially in the area of technology advancement. Because technology is a differentiator and it sells. We are looking at geographic diversification, especially Europe and Asia, because we have a smaller concentricity of our business there today, and we see a growing opportunity there.

I also already mentioned the vertical integration side of things. We'll look at what we can do in that respect. And we want to stick to our knitting, especially if there's opportunities out there to consolidate the space we operate in today with driveline, drivetrain, and metal form; we'll look at that. But we also are looking into the electronics and the mechatronic side of our business, because there's more and more demand for that on our current products, let alone what the megatrends are with connectivity and electrification and autonomous vehicles in the future.

So, that kind of gives you an idea where we are looking and then how we are prioritizing things from a strategic standpoint. And from a balance sheet standpoint, if it makes sense to use stock or equity or raise equity, we'll look at that. And we will be disciplined just like we have in everything else we've done in managing our business.

And if it presents itself as the right opportunity that's good for us, then we'll look at it. If not, then we'll pursue other means and paths. But just rest assured we'll be very disciplined and not put ourselves in a position where we overleverage our business when we've worked too hard to get to where we are at today.

CHRIS MAY: For five years, we've been building to have this flexibility. We've achieved that. We are certainly proud of that fact. But prudence would certainly evaluate in through our processes as we look at any M&A activity, for sure.

JOHN MURPHY: Great. Do we have any questions in the audience? I've got a bunch more, so -- okay. Well, one of the things that we've heard from GM as they are looking at the truck program, the next generation truck program, is that they are insourcing 20%, 30% of the program on axles.

Do you think that's something they are actually going to execute and allocate and build to capacity? Or maybe they award that to another supplier? That's the first step. And then second step is we think about the gradation of that lower revenue. When does that actually come in? And does that come in all at once? Or is this sort of a multiyear wind-down and there's still a long tail of opportunity to backfill?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes, I mean, the first thing -- I don't really want to comment -- GM has made a decision; we have commented on that with respect to we're going to maintain 75% of the business that we enjoy today. They are going to make a sourcing decision on the -- other 25% on the light-duty side of the business.

So, they really need to tell you what they are going to do in that area. All I can say is that we are very proud to partner with them going forward not for one generation but two generations of product. We are the industry leader when it comes to truck axles from a fuel efficiently standpoint, lightweighting overall performance standpoint. They've clearly made a strategic decision from a commodity management standpoint; maybe from a product know-how standpoint, because they had so much reliance and dependence on American Axle that they felt that they needed to make a change.

I didn't like it; I still don't like it today. I don't think it's the right decision on their behalf, especially when you look at the requirements that are out there with respect to autonomous vehicles, connectivity and electrification, which is where I think most of the OEMs are going to be spending their money. But at the same time, that decision has been made.

And therefore, I'm not going to cry about it. We're just going to pick up ourselves and carry forward. And there's other customers out there that can leverage that capacity, leverage our know-how and our capability. But again, very proud and pleased with the relationship we have with GM. But ultimately, they made a decision that, unfortunately, negatively -- will negatively impact going forward.

To your second part of your question, it starts impacting us in the 2018 calendar-year period of time. We will feel more effect in the 2019 period of time. We should feel the full effect of their sourcing decision by the 2020 period of time. But it also gives us anywhere between three to five years to offset that, based on other new business that we are quoting on and working on with non-GM customers today. And we are highly confident that we can replace that business either organically and/or strategically, based on the things we just talked about earlier.

JOHN MURPHY: And the margin return profile of the business that you're replacing it with, and as you diversify -- how do you think about that? I mean, in general, it seems hard to replace a program of this size and scale with the same margins. But if you could redeploy capital, the returns may be similar or may be potentially better, depending on what kind of global programs you ultimately win. How do you think of sort of the replacement business that could backfill for that?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. What we've said all along is that we enjoy 30-plus-percent contribution margins in regards to the full-size truck business that we enjoy today. As we're bringing on new business -- we are bringing that in, in the 20% -- 25% range. So we're naturally going to see some degradation in regards to our profitability from an overall margin standpoint to begin with.

You touched on the fact -- I mean, the other thing is our cost structure is improving along the way. At the same time, we are generating significant cash. We are able to redeploy a lot of those assets and avoid future CapEx requirements going forward. So, we still feel that we are going to have a very meaningful and very profitable business going forward. And as you know right now, we are performing at the high end of the peer group with respect to margin performance and against our direct competitors, much higher than where they are at this point in time.

CHRIS MAY: And that lower capital intensity that we can leverage, when we are bidding for new business in that time period, will certainly improve our financial profile, but also allow us to be more competitive in our bids, where we haven't had that luxury before and we were still winning business in the past. So this is kind of a double win for us as it relates to that concept.

JOHN MURPHY: I had a follow-up question on China and India.

DAVID DAUCH: Sure.

JOHN MURPHY: These are huge markets, and I think the investors that follow those sectors are pretty familiar with the competition on the OEM side and what OEMs are doing building vehicles there. But they are a little less, I think, knowledgeable on how the supplier universe works in those areas.

With the huge growth we are seeing in those two markets, what are some of the opportunities or challenges? Are OEMs vertically integrating axle product? Or are they looking for outside help? Because it seems like it's a huge untapped area.

DAVID DAUCH: In India and China specifically?

JOHN MURPHY: Yes.

DAVID DAUCH: Well, it's very clear in China that the Western OEMs are looking to put axle production on the outside. Mercedes is a prime example, or Daimler. We are doing their C/D class axles for them in China, as I mentioned earlier. A lot of the Western OEMs that are coming to China -- again, putting their business on the outside. We are participating in many programs with respect to that.

Some of the domestic OEMs within China -- some have invested in axles. They don't have the capability that we have from a technology standpoint, so they are living with inferior designs. But at the same time, it's a matter of how you balance -- balancing cost versus technology, and how the market is shifting that more from a cost-based market more towards a technology-based market.

India is still a cost-based market. Many OEMs are doing axles in-house, but we've conquested business from Tata. So Tata has sourced work with us. Ashok Leyland has sourced work with us. Daimler on the truck side -- commercial truck side, has sourced work with us. Isuzu has sourced work with us. So there's a lot of work that's going to the outside as well in India. Because again, the capital demands that they have on their own business, and yet there's reputable suppliers, like American Axle, that can provide good product on time every time for them.

JOHN MURPHY: Yes. So it's evolution of cost versus the content and quality?

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. Yes.

JOHN MURPHY: And I have one question on the tech center. How's that going? What's the development -- what are the developments there? What's the game plan? I mean, this is sort of a whole new animal for you guys and actually for a lot of suppliers to put together a big tech center like this to develop technology as well as showcase it. I was just curious if you could talk about that.

DAVID DAUCH: Yes. And what John is referring to is we made a commitment and publicly announced we are building an advanced technology development center in our Detroit campus. It's a 300,000 square foot facility that's going to be dedicated to working on all of our advanced technology from a product processing systems capability; a $20-million-plus investment.

We've already got 150 people already in the facility today, and that will only grow as we go forward. We're going to be doing all of our benchmarking of our competitive products, you know, for current business today. At the same time, we are proving out all of our products, so that when they do go to our facilities for production, we are not experiencing any launch issues. So we are much more disciplined from an operational standpoint that way.

We are also putting in things from a 3-D manufacturing standpoint. We are looking at material labs, gear labs, other things that, again, will leverage the technology that's available in the marketplace today that maybe wasn't there in the past or even there today, but in the future, with what can be done with the cloud, what can be done with some of the technology and the connectivity of machines-to-machines, and other things.

So I'm very, very excited about where we are today. At the same time, we are setting up a customer showcase place where we can demonstrate all of our technology to them on our current business as well as future technology that we are bringing out. And it's a three-year evolution. We are in the 1 1/2 years; we're halfway through it right now. So by the end of next year, we should be in great shape.

JOHN MURPHY: Great. And then I've got -- I'm going to keep going. I mean, as you look at your cost base as it exists right now, I mean, you guys spearheaded some of the moves -- or on the earlier curve, I should say -- necessarily of moving some of your manufacturing base and labor to Mexico. Obviously a lot of your labor has moved to Eastern Europe.

Is there more for you to do in that direction as far as working on your cost base? Really what do you think that does for your cost or ongoing cost structure and your flexibility, and your ability to service your clients or your customers?

DAVID DAUCH: I think we are very well-positioned today. Our business was predominantly in the Midwest in the past before. We had an OEM cost structure based on the way the business was bought and sold back in 1994. I think most of the people that have followed American Axle recognize that we had very difficult labor negotiations in 2008 with the UAW, and endured an 87-day work stoppage. But we did that because we didn't have a sustainable cost structure going forward, and we were carrying an OEM cost structure, not a Tier 1 automotive supplier.

Because of that strike, it resulted in incremental capacity being put in Mexico. So some of that work stayed in Mexico; did not come back. Most of our initiative in Mexico, most of our initiatives around the world, isn't to ship product back to the US. It's really to support the local markets for themselves.

But because of the strike situation, we had to not only protect ourselves, we had to protect our customers. And that's why some of the capacity was put into place in Mexico. We still have large axle operation in our Three Rivers, Michigan facility. We have good labor harmony there now, so that's very positive for us.

We've invested $150 million in taking the plant from 400 associates to 1,800 associates. So, the relationships there -- and it's got our latest technology with respect to disconnecting all-wheel-drive. So we don't see a lot more activity that we need to do from a geographic footprint standpoint. During the tough times of 2008, 2009, 2010, even during those tough times, we made strategic decision to invest in rounding out our global footprint.

And now we are in the process of filling up that global footprint, and -- but we are in a very cost-competitive situation, like you said, in Eastern Europe, in China, in India, in Brazil and Thailand, based on where the market is for us, and being in close proximity to our customer.

So we are not in Russia today; don't have any big plans to go there. We are evaluating South Africa as it relates to the market, but we will only go there if the right book of business prevents itself. Other than that, we're going to leverage the installed facilities and capacities that we have in place today.

JOHN MURPHY: Over in raw materials, the steel prices have certainly been volatile and I know you probably have some sort of long-term contracts, but has that continued to be a tailwind? How do you kind of look at the next few years on the commodity front?

DAVID DAUCH: No, I mean -- we're the largest forger in North America and one of the top forgers in the world. We are the largest buyer of what we call SBQ or Special Bar Quality steel. So we don't buy flat steel; we buy bar steel for our forging applications. So we have a lot of might and clout with the steel mills because of the buying -- what we are buying today.

But we also have outstanding relationships with our supplier partners. And we do have multiyear contracts. We have good visibility in regards to what our pricing is going to be. And because of our buying power and economy of scales, it benefits us, which helps our competitiveness in our metal form business, and not to mention our driveline business as well.

We don't see a lot of instability in the materials markets today or going forward. And at the same time, as we are globalizing our business, we are bringing new suppliers in and new markets that are more cost-competitive in some cases. At the same time, we are partnering with many of our suppliers to really -- that have the depth and the breadth and the financial wherewithal to really support us on a global basis and locate close to our facilities, so we can deliver things on a landed cost basis competitively.

CHRIS MAY: Right. Close.

DAVID DAUCH: I don't know if, Chris, anything you want to add?

CHRIS MAY: Yes. No, and just also I would remind you, keep in mind as it relates to some of the more highly variable elements of our material buys that are tied to indices, about 80% to 90% of those are passed through to the customer, whether in the form of a benefit or an increase. So, certainly in periods of declining prices, we get a select benefit, and in periods where the prices are rising, there is a slight decrement. But as you know, it's pretty stable as it looks right now.

JOHN MURPHY: I just have one last question on labor. I mean, there's been a lot of press about -- I think it's Lear and Matt Simoncini who's been pushing this a little bit -- of trying to work with or publicize the fact that if there was cost-effective labor in the Detroit area, they would be willing to put investments in place and build a base of business there.

I think they are working on some facility downtown. They're starting to ramp up. Would you ever consider moving -- presuming it's cost-effective -- moving some of that capacity back north or putting more capital in place if you had a more friendly labor environment in Michigan or in the Detroit area? Or at this point, is everything kind of set the way it's set, and you would only do that to follow the customers, at this point?

DAVID DAUCH: No, to answer -- the short answer to your question is if the right opportunity presented itself to put the business back in Detroit, we would do that. Matt is working on some things, but his thought process is more of how can he bring work out of Mexico and bring it back? And he needs a certain competitive labor structure in order to do that. It's very hard to compare the US labor structure to the Mexican labor structure.

And what he's asking from the UAW -- I don't know is -- if it's really realistic. Okay? Otherwise you are going to have a lot of transition in that facility. I applaud his efforts. Matt and I are working on a Detroit task force team to bring jobs. We are probably the two suppliers that are spearheading and driving -- trying to bring jobs back to Detroit because of our commitment to Detroit.

On the other hand, as I said, we have a very good working relationship today with the UAW. We have worked through a difficult time in 2008 but very good working relationship with them. We've identified what we think is the right competitive cost structure to compete in Detroit. And it's -- you just can't have an entitlement mentality. And that's what existed in the past before.

We've explained to them what market competitive prices are for a Tier 1 automotive supplier in the driveline space, both wages and benefits. We can cut it any way, but it can't exceed a certain level in order to be competitive. So, I'm not looking at really moving the capacity and bringing it back from Mexico as much as I'm looking at making incremental investments if it made business sense, based on new business that's presented itself, because of the increased demand for truck capacity right now and crossover vehicle capacity, and possibly an electrification capacity in the future.

JOHN MURPHY: Great. And with that, I think we are running light on time. So we really appreciate you guys coming. It's great to have you here and good luck with the rest of the presentation.

DAVID DAUCH: Thanks, John. Appreciate it.

urn:contentItem:606K-F8X1-JBJN-M24J-00000-00American Companies Need to Hang Up on Beijing2020-06-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisAmerican Companies Need to Hang Up on BeijingOliver McPherson-Smith

<p>The COVID-19 global pandemic has made video conference calling a basic tool for both socializing and business alike. But recent revelations that Zoom closed American accounts on demands from Beijing point to a worrying trend of American companies muting basic rights to accommodate autocrats abroad. When companies ride roughshod over American values overseas, their actions have tangible negative implications for American consumers at home.</p><p>Earlier this month the video calling platform Zoom confirmed that it had suspended or terminated several accounts used to host public vigils for the Tiananmen Square massacre at the request of the Chinese government. Two of the now-reinstated accounts were based in the US, while another was based in Hong Kong.

Following public outcry, Zoom says it will unveil more sophisticated tools to only target accounts that are actually based in mainland China.</p><p>But Zoom is not the only American company to grapple with balancing the economic opportunity of the Chinese market with Beijing’s aversion to freedom of speech and privacy. Following a massive Chinese-based hacking attack in 2010 and a tense relationship with Beijing, Google began winding down its operations in the People’s Republic. But by 2018 it was revealed that Google was developing a search engine that would comply with China’s censorship demands, dubbed Project Dragonfly. The decision was met with swift backlash from rights advocates and Google’s own employees, forcing the company to publicly abandon the project.</p><p>Far from the world of Big Tech, even the NBA has come under immense pressure to censor comments that the Chinese Communist Party dislikes. In October 2019, Houston Rockets Manager Daryl Morey tweeted an image that read, ‘Stand for Freedom Stand with Hong Kong,’ in support of then-ongoing protests. While the NBA quickly distanced itself from the comments, that move garnered backlash from politicians on both sides of the aisle.</p><p>NBA commissioner Adam Silver later clarified that the NBA would not regulate what players, employees, or owners would say. But almost all of the NBA’s local Chinese sponsors suspended their partnerships with the league, and Lakers star LeBron James denounced Morey, saying that “he wasn’t educated on the situation at hand.”</p><p>When American companies acquiesce to Beijing’s crackdown on rights, their actions have tangible ripple effects for American consumers. Zoom’s new censorship feature will only suspend Chinese accounts—but it will also limit Americans’ abilities to communicate with foreign counterparts in mainland China. Similarly, Beijing’s pressure on sports figures risks reshaping what American players and managers will say to American fans on American soil. In an international marketplace, the effects of these censorship efforts do not stop at American borders.</p><p>It is not a new idea that companies shouldn’t check their American values at the door when they operate abroad. The Kimberley Process and the Clean Diamond Trade Act (2003), for example, seek to stop blood diamonds from making their way into the American market. Similarly, the Treasury Department’s expansive sanctions program limits the ability of American companies to do business with state-sponsors of terrorism, such as Iran. These programs recognize that the line between the American and international economy is thin, and American consumers have an interest in protecting basic rights.</p><p>In a globalized world, American companies will continue to face the challenge of balancing their own values with the demands of unscrupulous actors abroad. But yielding to crackdowns on basic rights like freedom of speech and privacy abroad also effects American consumers. As the costs associated with appeasing the Chinese Communist Party become increasingly apparent, American businesses should consider hanging up on their demands.</p><h3 class="related_post_title">Further Reading</h3><ul class="related_post wp_rp"><li data-position="0" data-poid="in-13613" data-post-type="none" >Inside Sources: Federal Ban on Huawei Protects Both National Security and Consumers</li><li data-position="1" data-poid="in-12274" data-post-type="none" >China’s Plague of Cyber Breaches</li><li data-position="2" data-poid="in-13245" data-post-type="none" >China Plays the Rare Earth Card, Again</li><li data-position="3" data-poid="in-13008" data-post-type="none" >China’s Internet Propaganda Seeks to Manage U.S. Consumer Perceptions</li><li data-position="4" data-poid="in-12246" data-post-type="none" >Huawei and Its Reputational Challenges</li><li data-position="5" data-poid="in-14528" data-post-type="none" >Emergency Small Business Loans are Leaving Out Local Media Outlets</li></ul>

urn:contentItem:5Y0W-PSX1-DXH2-62RT-00000-00American Dystopia: California In Crisis; New Hillary Documentary Looks Like Campaign Ad; A Plan To Pack The Union With New States; Bias In Silicon Valley; VA Democrats Introduce Gun Control Bills Ahead Of Rally; Satire Site Under Fire For Poking Fun At The Left; EPA Exists To Protect You And The Environment2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisTUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT8:00 PM ESTEthan Bearman, Drew Pinsky, Buck Sexton, Blake Harris, Seth DillonNEWSDomestic011701cb.260American Dystopia: California In Crisis; New Hillary Documentary Looks Like Campaign Ad; A Plan To Pack The Union With New States; Bias In Silicon Valley; VA Democrats Introduce Gun Control Bills Ahead Of Rally; Satire Site Under Fire For Poking Fun At The Left; EPA Exists To Protect You And The EnvironmentTucker Carlson, Trace Gallagher

MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: So we will see you back here on Monday night at seven and then we start the impeachment week, folks. So hang in there with us. Have a good weekend. We'll see you then.

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

Say what you want about the 2020 presidential race, it's not what they used to call a managerial election. It's not a contest to determine which branch of the establishment gets a turn of the wheel. This isn't a Clinton-Dole '96 kind of race where you're pretty sure that no matter who wins, things aren't really going to change very much.

This year, the one thing you can be certain of is that things could be very different when it's over. The issues at stake are bigger than just the economy or even our foreign policy commitments. 2020 is about the broadest possible questions. What kind of country should we have? Who should live here? What will America look like 50 years from now?

There are a lot of possible answers to those questions, but leading Democrats appear to have settled on their position. America, they're telling us should be a lot more like California.

Listen to former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg explain his vision for the country he is hoping to lead.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL BLOOMBERG (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I think that California can serve as a great example for the rest of this country. You have led the way on climate change, on fighting gun violence and on criminal justice, and you have as importantly, opened immigrants with open arms.

California is part of this country that is something the rest of the country looks up to.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So Michael Bloomberg graduated from high school, almost 60 years ago. And at that time, a lot of what he just said was true. The rest of the country really did look up to California. Millions of Americans moved to California in search of a better life. It had the nation's best public schools, you know, a world class universities that essentially were free.

Graduates from those universities created Silicon Valley, among other things, the birthplace of the Digital Age. Compared to the rest of America, poverty in California then was low, and opportunity was virtually unlimited.

The people who moved here in 1960 when Bloomberg graduated high school found their American dream.

But things have changed. Now, the children and grandchildren of those people are fleeing California.

We spent the last week here in Los Angeles for the show, and in some ways, it's still a very beautiful place. The western parts of the city are some of the richest neighborhoods in the world. You'd want to live there. They're immaculate, nice people.

But huge swaths of modern Los Angeles shock the conscience of anyone who drives by. Filth and disorder and clusters of homeless addicts. Tent cities continue for block after block. This is footage from one of our producers, Charlie Cougar, shot yesterday.

California has 12 percent of the world's population, but it has a quarter of this country's homeless. Adjusted for the cost of living, California has the highest poverty rate of any state in America. Nearly a quarter of its people are poor. Why?

Well, there are a lot of reasons, but here are some. The state has the most expensive housing in the continental United States. It has the most expensive gasoline, thanks to the taxes. The free world class universities, those are long gone.

The University of California system has some of the highest in-state tuition rates in the country. As we chronicled last week in our series, "American Dystopia," no city more accurately represents the implosion of California than San Francisco.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Get the [bleep] out of here. [Bleep] old ass [bleep].

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I've been here 42 years before you were [bleep] born. [Bleep] off.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: [Bleep] you. I'll [bleep] kill you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm scared for my safety.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You never know what's coming around the corner.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes, film me, mother [bleep].

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Bit into my arm.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I live a block away. [Bleep] you.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This city is messed up. It is very messed up.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I'm not forcing him to move, but I talk to him and encourage him to get to move.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Do you think you'll be homeless for the rest of your life?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Yes.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You put them out and in what state?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: It's messed up, really messed up. That's right. And so finally normal people are leaving California. For decades, the state led the nation in attracting migrants from other states. Now, the flow has reversed.

Every year, the number of people leaving California for other places exceeds the number of people moving in by more than a hundred thousand. If it weren't for the constant stream of immigrants from abroad, California's population would be falling and fast.

The middle class utopia of old has evaporated. The state is in crisis. Now, that's obvious to everyone who lives here, certainly, but not to the people who run California.

Instead of fixing the problems that are forcing people to flee, politicians here have spent the last few years on policies that are frivolous and counterproductive: Banning plastic straws, requiring background checks to buy shotgun shells, legalizing the intentional transmission of HIV.

Governor Gavin Newsom's most recent budget proposes $80 million in additional funding to provide free healthcare for illegal immigrant seniors. Who wants that?

This is the state the Democrats are calling the model for America. The state they want your state to be more like, at least you know what the election is about.

Ethan Bearman is a California radio host. He joins us tonight. Ethan, thanks so much for coming on. It's great to be back in the state where I'm from. It's beautiful. The rich areas are nicer than ever.

But in the last four nights, I've had four dinners and every person has said I love California and I'm preparing to leave because it's falling apart. How can this be a model that Democrats point to?

ETHAN BEARMAN, RADIO HOST: Well, it's still the fifth biggest economy in the entire world. We have a strong economic engine. We have Hollywood. We have Silicon Valley. We grow a third of the food for the entire United States. There are huge opportunities.

One out of seven jobs created during the Trump tenure were actually created here in California even though we're only one eighth the population, so there's a lot still happening here.

We have a brand new governor who is finally, finally taking bold action on the two biggest issues that everything relates back to that you are talking about: Housing and homelessness. And he is finally going to take a strong lead on that.

CARLSON: You know, he said he was going to take a strong lead on it when he was the Mayor of San Francisco, and he did absolutely nothing, and in fact, it got even worse. And that's been true of the past five mayors of San Francisco, the past three governors of the state. It is a one-party state. The State Senate has been controlled by Democrats for 50 years.

There hasn't been a Republican mayor of San Francisco in 56 years. So this is a Democratic problem. And it's getting worse, not better. I don't know why nationally, Democrats aren't ashamed of it.

BEARMAN: Well, here's the issue. So while you're right in terms of those data points, we've had Republican governors through that whole process. But the issue with the housing problem which is a core issue that's happening here, we're short three and a half million units of housing. That's why it's so expensive, simple supply and demand.

CARLSON: Yes.

BEARMAN: If you're short that many.

CARLSON: That's right.

BEARMAN: And it's been a combination of people on the left and the right at the local level, at the county level, at the state level. Nimbies who say I don't want this environmentalist on the left, as well, absolutely, who say we have to be careful of how we build. It's expensive. We need to streamline that process. We have SB-50 that's happening in the legislature right now.

CARLSON: Well, can I just ask a question that I've been wondering about a week -- why is no one pointing to the cause of the overcrowding, which is immigration? The state is too crowded. You can't get anywhere.

The infrastructure is clogged, it's choked and that's because there are too many people and so the very people who say we're going to fix the housing problem are saying, we're going to invite in millions of new people and give them free healthcare. Is there -- I mean, has logic been suspended, or am I missing something?

BEARMAN: I don't think that people are inviting millions of people to California.

CARLSON: By offering free healthcare to illegal aliens?

BEARMAN: I don't believe that invites people whatsoever.

CARLSON: Are you being serious?

BEARMAN: Yes, absolutely. We've talked about this before. If I have kids and I'm living in a country in Central America and a gang threatens to kill them if I don't do their bidding in the cartels, I'm going to flee as well.

CARLSON: Well, wait a second. If you're walking down the street and you -- and you're not that hungry and you pass a restaurant that says free pizza. Would you go in? Of course, you would. Because there's free pizza.

BEARMAN: I like pizza.

CARLSON: Right. Who doesn't? I do, too, as you can tell. So if you say to the rest of the world, your single biggest problem is healthcare. We're going to give it to you for free and not kick you out. Why wouldn't you be invited by that?

BEARMAN: Because these people are already here. They're already our neighbors. They're part of our communities. They're already going to emergency rooms, which is far more expensive than preventative care.

CARLSON: But wait, wait, wait a second. You've got -- we just read you the numbers. You've got thousands of native-born Californians leaving every year primarily for Texas, but also Idaho and the contiguous states -- Oregon, Arizona. Why wouldn't you be worried about them?

BEARMAN: Oh, we are worried about them.

CARLSON: Really? Because I don't see the governor doing anything about their flight.

BEARMAN: And that's what goes back to the things like SB-50, to work on the housing issue. We have local cities, Republican-leaning cities who refuse to build housing, and when that is -- what's happening is that's what's killing the supply and the demand.

CARLSON: So the homelessness in the state which is controlled wholly by the Democratic Party, they've got a super majority in the legislature, you're telling me with a straight face is being caused by Republicans. Is that what you're saying?

BEARMAN: No, I am saying that it is definitely being contributed to. That's not exclusively a Democratic issue. But what is --

CARLSON: Will you concede that if you have a lot more people in a confined area, it's more crowded, there's more traffic and the housing is more expensive.

BEARMAN: As long as people are having more than two kids, that is going to be the case.

CARLSON: No, actually native born people in California are leaving. It's a hundred percent an immigration problem. Will you at least concede that inviting people from other countries, I'm sure they're all great people, it doesn't matter, makes the state poorer and more crowded? I mean, what else has happened?

BEARMAN: Well, I don't fully agree with that either. It depends on who the immigrants are and where they're coming from. We know that we have immigrants coming from wealthy European nations.

CARLSON: Absolutely. And I'm not -- this is not about ethnicity. It's about numbers. The state is too crowded, will you concede to that or no?

BEARMAN: So I don't. I don't. I don't agree with that. And the reason why is because we can address that, we can build housing. We do have processes in place that --

CARLSON: We could make it Hong Kong. Why would we want to do that?

BEARMAN: Or Singapore, but why not? Why not have more people? People are continuing -- as long as people have kids and our entire economy is based on growth which in the United States it is, otherwise, our system starts collapsing if we're not growing. Look at what happened with Japan.

CARLSON: Yes.

BEARMAN: Then we need to build --

CARLSON: Right. I get it. That's just not actually working. I mean, it's one of those theories that at the Chicago School they tell us is true, but it turns out isn't. Ethan, great to see you.

BEARMAN: Thanks, Tucker.

CARLSON: Los Angeles' homeless population is estimated at 59,000 people. So if all of those got together and became a city, they'd rank as the 31st of LA counties 88 cities. If you move them to Vermont, they'd be the largest city in the state, just the homeless, just here.

The surging homeless population in LA combined with the toleration of garbage and feces and used needles they produce is becoming an absolute health hazard, for real, not a talking point.

Last year, the city suffered outbreak of typhus, thanks for the surging rat population feasting on garbage on city streets. Last year, we profiled a victim of that on the show.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: But far away from Skid Row, through rats and fleas, typhus traveled through the streets and the Deputy City Attorney who works way up on the sixth floor at City Hall got infected.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH GREENWOOD, DEPUTY CITY ATTORNEY: I felt like I was going to die.

The homeless population has moved closer and closer. They surround the building. So as folks walk to work and back, they're walking through rotting food, raw sewage.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

CARLSON: Yes, it's not the medieval period. It's just a one party state. Dr. Drew Pinsky hosts "The Dr. Drew Podcast." He joins us tonight. Doctor, thanks so much for coming on.

DR. DREW PINSKY, HOST, "THE DR. DREW PODCAST": Thank you.

CARLSON: Typhus?

PINSKY: Typhus, my own home became overrun with rats, and when I saw that I thought, oh, we're going to have a typhus outbreak. I practice Medicine against the foothills here long enough to know that's what coming.

What scares me is they've done nothing to reduce the rodent population. And what is endemic in this area after typhus, is something called Yersinia. You may know it as plague. So I'm worried that we're going to have that next.

The city you talked about, 60,000 people on the streets defecating, feces flowing into the LA River bypassing sewage treatment, a city the size almost of Pasadena is bypassing sewage treatment. We're having mammalian -- sea mammal die off, we're worried about turtled straws. It's unbelievable.

CARLSON: So why isn't the -- and as somebody who cares about --

PINSKY: Where are the environmentalists? Where are they? I need them.

CARLSON: You know that's it. That's it right there. Where are they?

In humans atrazine is an endocrine disrupter. That means it causes changes to your natural hormonal balance. For newborn boys, atrazine exposure in utero is correlated with lower birth weight, undescended testicles and deformities to sex organs.

Buried within a recent 60-page regulatory document, the EPA has announced it will soon end its Atrazine Monitoring Program, which tests drinking water to make certain that atrazine levels are safe.

According to the EPA, the risk is simply so low that it's not worth even checking to make sure the situation is under control. In fact, it's so low they're allowing 50 percent more atrazine to enter America's waterways.

Now, that's despite the fact that in 2017, the year with the most recent data are public, 30 million Americans had measurable amounts of atrazine in their tap water.

Now, according to researchers at Purdue University, a single part per billion of atrazine may be linked to low birth weights. In Evansville, Illinois, the water is already testing at 22 parts per billion. For the EPA, that's not a concern. Their concern is corn.

When President Trump ran in 2016 on keeping America out of Middle Eastern quagmires, we came close to getting in one last week after the assassination of Qasem Soleimani and then Iran's retaliatory missile strikes. It looks like we're on the brink there for a minute. In the end, of course, we avoided it.

The question is, what does the public think of the whole thing? Well, a new Morning Consult poll finds this -- fascinating -- 71 percent of voters approved have not attacking Iran. Just 14 percent disapprove.

Imagine that. Avoiding far off wars is popular. You could win an election on that. We will be back Monday. Have a great night. Sean Hannity is next.

urn:contentItem:5S5F-NFK1-F03R-N0F8-00000-00America Needs Congressmembers Like Ro Khanna And Kaniela Ing To Watch What Facebook Is Up To2018-04-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisAmerica Needs Congressmembers Like Ro Khanna And Kaniela Ing To Watch What Facebook Is Up ToDownWithTyranny

Apr 23, 2018( DownWithTyranny: http://downwithtyranny.com Delivered by Newstex)   https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-VF8hRu1S3w8/Wtuwh5-t1kI/AAAAAAABYfw/IqDG9zAEGeAUVoxQBYwAGqpmcchzxFh1ACLcBGAs/s1600/RoKhanna.png If you watched the Senate Commerce Committee and Senate Judiciary Committee "grilling" Mark Zuckerberg a few weeks ago... well it wasn't as bad as when Alaska SenatorTed Stevens explaining[1] net neutrality and the internet in terms of a series of tubes and big trucks just over a decade ago. But almost. They're old.

And they have staffers who type for them. Play Video[2]Ro Khanna, the progressive congressman who represents Silicon Valley was dismayed[3]-- "less" wrote Alex Nazaryan for Newsweek "because of what the Facebook co-founder and chairman did say-- for the most part, bromides about privacy, security and censorship-- than because of what the lawmakers arrayed before him didn't." Ro is a calm and composed fella. One can only imagine if Hawaii state Rep-- and congressional candidate-- Kaniela Ing was sitting next to him. 'This was a missed opportunity,' Khanna lamented later that evening in a text message. 'The hearing revealed a knowledge gap in Congress about technology.' Many of the men and women questioning Zuckerberg were about twice his age, and some were quite a bit older than that. They knew that adversaries like Russia had weaponized social media networks like Facebook and Twitter, but the particulars of the problem clearly eluded them. The 44 legislators who took turns quizzing Zuckerberg showed only a cursory understanding of data collection and encryption, and the lengthy hearing quickly devolved into the kind of exasperating technology tutorial one dreads having to give aging relatives.It was an amusing day for the purveyors of humorous internet memes. But anyone anxious about the obviously uneasy marriage between democracy and digital technology would not have been reassured. Zuckerberg left Capitol Hill without having to explain in any appreciable detail the failure that brought him there in the first place: the improper use of data belonging to 87 million Facebook users by data research firm Cambridge Analytica, which was conducting microtargeting work for Donald Trump's presidential campaign. He did offer apologies and reassurances, but these were vague enough to not be especially reassuring.Only eight years older than Zuckerberg, Khanna has been called 'Silicon Valley's ambassador to Middle America.' California's 17th congressional district, which he has represented since 2017, is home to some of the most successful corporations in the world: Apple (market value: $892 billion, as of April 16), Intel ($245 billion), Yahoo (now part of Verizon, whose market capitalization stands at $197 billion) and Tesla ($50 billion). Alphabet ($726 billion), with its Googleplex, is one district over, as is Facebook ($480 billion), with its thumbs-up icon announcing its Menlo Park Headquarters, at 1 Hacker Way.That address captures the mood of Silicon Valley a decade ago: whimsical, cheeky, maybe even hubristic. This was before anyone had ever heard of the Internet Research Agency, where Vladimir Putin's minions were waging a new kind of war. Psychographic data, of the kind Cambridge Analytica supposedly collected, was not yet for sale to politicians looking for an edge. Trolls were the stuff of medieval legend. And coding savants could not have expected to be lectured by the likes of Senators Chuck Grassley and Dean Heller, as Zuckerberg was earlier this month. The thumb is still there, at 1 Hacker Way, but the joke is no longer funny.'I believe representing Silicon Valley is one of the most important jobs in American politics,' Khanna says. To represent Silicon Valley is to speak and account for a techno elite given far more to self-celebration than introspection. Aware of the region's surpassingly good fortunes, and of its closely related tendency to hubris, Khanna has tried to export the former while arguing that it is necessary to tame the latter. He believes that the success of the tech sector is replicable and could serve as economic balm for other parts of the nation, particularly those where mining or manufacturing can no longer vault blue-collar workers into the middle class. Despite troubling disclosures about Facebook and its peers, he believes that most any community would welcome Zuckerberg, along with his Cambridge Analytica problem.The same week that Zuckerberg testified on Capitol Hill, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi selected Khanna to draft an Internet Bill of Rights. It was a significant show of confidence in the House freshman by Pelosi, a veteran of the chamber renowned for her political acumen. Although it is impossible to say what an Internet Bill of Rights will look like, Khanna has long proposed such a measure to give Internet users clarity over the data they share as they click through Facebook photos or shop on Amazon.The Internet Bill of Rights would, in turn, prove a major test of just how much regulation Silicon Valley is willing to countenance. Big Tech has been a remarkably cagey industry, in part because it knows it gives us what nobody else can. It knows that even as we complain about hegemony, we order diapers on Amazon, instead of walking to the corner store. World leaders spar on Twitter, while chefs who once wanted to impress critics now think about what will look good on Instagram. At the same time, Reddit trolls disseminate fake news, which Google algorithms uncritically promote, while terrorists talk freely on WhatsApp, protected by the messaging service's encryption. Silicon Valley is becoming a victim of its own explosive growth, like the too-big-to-fail Wall Street banks that failed in 2008, plunging the nation into a recession.Khanna is aware of souring public opinion and has tried to both acknowledge it and reshape it. 'You can't be an island of success,' he says of the district he represents. 'We have to answer the nation's call.' If Silicon Valley can answer that call with 'humility,' Khanna says, the tech behemoths can avoid the kind of onerous regulation other liberal legislators are calling for, such as the General Data Protection Regulation that will go into effect in Europe in 2018.Khanna's indefatigable optimism has positioned him as a potential leader in a Democratic Party unable to reconcile its progressive and centrist elements and desperate for new faces. As a member of the Progressive Caucus, Khanna has advocated for liberal policies such as expansion of the earned-income tax credit. But his corporate past—- and corporate constituency—- keep him from veering too far into the sort of political fantasy for which Northern California is sometimes known. He may be just what the party needs, a moderate by temperament but by no means a centrist.'You can have a bold progressive vision coming from Silicon Valley, rooted in patriotism,' Khanna says. 'And I guess the case study is they elected me.'..."This is a huge opportunity for tech leaders to work with Congress,' Khanna says. Otherwise, he warns, the regulatory power will fall to 'a bunch of bureaucrats who, frankly, don't know much about tech,' intellectual siblings of the senators who haplessly interrogated Zuckerberg. If regulation is inevitable, better that regulation be informed by the industry in question.https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-RJRRAoiJd9U/WtuwSlm8pkI/AAAAAAABYfs/0NCrKVv_f9EDIKkBkCLkXUllnSwzBwc8ACLcBGAs/s1600/ing_850_444.jpgBack to Kaniela for a moment. He's already taken on Zuckerberg... and won[4]. Kate Arnoff, writing for In These Times explained how in 2014, "Zuckerberg purchased 700 acres of beachfront property on land Native Hawaiians have gathering rights to. Then he built a wall around it, and sued local families to keep them out. Ing helped lead the charge from the state legislature for Native Hawaiians to reclaim their rights to that land, and Zuckerberg eventually dropped the lawsuits. Now, Ing, a Native Hawaiian, is running to represent Hawaii's first congressional district, with a critique of Facebook and other corporations that extends well beyond their CEOs' real estate investments. In Washington, Ing hopes to curtail corporate power, and regulate Facebook and other major tech firms like utilities." Kaniela: We know what it's like to be up against oligarchy in Hawaii. We've lived in a feudal society and a really unequal capitalist society throughout history. Now we're seeing that repeat. We have three men in American who hold more wealth than the bottom half-- than 50 percent of the entire nation. And 82 percent of new wealth generated in 2017 went to the top 1 percent. It's more stark than ever. Mark Zuckerberg is one of today's oligarchs, just like on the mainland with Standard Oil and some of the other oligarchs in the past. Except now these guys have control over commerce, like Amazon, and communications, like Facebook. And that's where it gets really dangerous for a democracy. It's important that Congress act now and not rely on self-regulation by these monopolists.   https://secure.actblue.com/contribute/page/blueamerica18?refcode=thermometer...Zuckerberg calls Facebook a social utility. And if he's admitting it's a utility he should agree that it should be treated like one. The same goes for the internet in general, not just social networks but broadband connection. It's a necessity now in the modern world, the way electricity was almost a century ago. There was way too much control by a few corporations that actually didn't benefit the majority of the public. So the government took over lines and-- at the very least-- heavily regulated these monopolies to make sure that everybody had equal access to electricity. We're going to have to do that for broadband generally, and we're going to have to do that for social networks. Right now there's nothing stopping someone like Zuckerberg from adjusting their algorithms to punish people with certain political views or certain companies. Arguably it's already happening. A lot of independent news sources don't have the same ability to reach their own followers that more corporate news sources do. That's unfair.If you'd like to help Kaniela win his race-- against 3 conservative barely Dems from the Republican wing of the Democratic Party-- please click on the thermometer above and contribute what you can to his campaign. You want to see real change in Congress? There's no one who's out to do that, and ready to do that, like Kaniela. urn:contentItem:5X1J-M351-F15W-H32T-00000-00American Enterprise Institute Holds Discussion on Technology and Legal Issues2019-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisAmerican Enterprise Institute Holds Discussion on Technology and Legal Issues

American Enterprise Institute Holds Discussion On Technology And Legal Issues

September 06, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

AEI SCHOLAR JAMES PETHOKOUKIS

BOSTON UNIVERSITY LAW PROFESSOR DANIELLE CITRON

AEI VISITING FELLOW JIM HARPER

US NAVAL ACADEMY ASSISTANT PROFESSOR JEFF KOSSEFF

[*]PETHOKOUKIS: I think we'll--I think we'll get started. If anybody else shows up late, well, they showed up late. They can just barge through that door.

Morning. I'm Jim Pethokoukis of the American Enterprise Institute, and this fantastic event you've chosen to attend, watch online, or view on C-SPAN is, should we reform Section 230? I'd like to start things off with an interpretive reading of Section 230 of the 1996 Communications and Decency Act.

It is not a long section. It is brief but important, and it states as follows, "No provider or user of an interactive computer service shall be treated as a publisher or speaker of any information provided by another information content provider." Now, for more than 20 years since the birth of the internet age as we know it, Section 230 has provided websites with immunity from liability from what their users post.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation describes the importance of Section 230 this way, "This legal and policy framework has allowed for YouTube to upload their own videos, Amazon, and Yelp to offer countless user reviews. Craigslist to host classified ads, and Facebook and Twitter to offer social networking to billions of internet users."

Given the sheer size of user-generated websites, it would be impossible and unfeasible for online intermediaries to prevent objectionable content from cropping up on their site. In short, Section 230 is perhaps the most influential law to protect the kind of innovation that has allowed the internet to thrive since 1996.

And yet over the past few years, Section 230 has faced heightened criticism from both the left and the right. Many critics on the left argue that social media giants enjoy special protection without any responsibility. They allow speech without worrying about its consequences, resulting in harassments and the increased prevalence of hate speech online.

Then other critics on the right have argued that these companies have gone too far in policing for these devices, or at least have too far in policing conservative voices, and enacted a biased double standard when it comes to content moderation.

In light of these criticisms and in line with a bipartisan political backlash against big tech, we've seen calls to reform Section 230. And it is these calls in this debate that we are going to discuss today. And I often use the phrase all-star panel. This time I mean it especially. This is an all-star panel.

Immediately to my right is Danielle Citron, author of the 2014 book, Hate Crimes in Cyberspace. She is also a professor of Law at Boston University School of Law where she teaches rights about privacy and free speech.

Next to Danielle is Jim Harper, a visiting fellow at AEI, where he focuses on privacy issues and select legal and constitutional law issues. And over on the end there is Jeff Kosseff, assistant professor of Cyber Security Law at the Naval Academy's Cyber Science Department and author of the recently released book, The Twenty-Six Words that Created the Internet, also a podcast guest on the AEI Political Economy podcast. Welcome all.

Let me start with--let me start with Jeff. What do we know for sure--we know reasonably for sure--was the intent behind Section 230? Why-why did legislators feel the need to bring it into being?

KOSSEFF: So, there were two main reasons when you look at the legislative history and when you talk with the people who were involved in drafting and advocating for Section 230. The first was there was really a concern at the time about --which, it's kind of quaint--legal pornography that was available to children online. That was the biggest concern about the Internet at the time.

And there was a series of court rulings under the common law and the First Amendment, which basically stood for the proposition that if you did not moderate content, you could actually increase your chances of being protected from liability for all user content. But if you started to moderate, then you could expose yourself to liability for defamation and other types of harm. So, there was really a concern, then, that this system was giving an incentive for platforms not to moderate. So, that was one driver of Section of 230.

The other was you have to think about the time. It was 1995. The modern internet was really at its infancy, and Congress wanted to get regulation and lawsuits out of the way of the development of this new technology. So, between those two reasons--those were really the driving forces behind Section 230.

PETHOKOUKIS: So, is there--I sense--and, again, everyone can sort of jump in. You don't need me to call on you. I should have mentioned that earlier.
