I just don't trust Congress to do--we could craft something brilliant, the four of us up here or all the folks in the room, and get together, and we could put together a perfect legislative history and send it down the street. And what we get back might be something radically different. So, I don't--I would be very hesitant to open up 230 to Congress right now.

KOSSEFF: I mean, the decisions are being made by lawyers. I assume there are a number of lawyers in this room.

PETHOKOUKIS: Yes.

KOSSEFF: We're all risk-averse people. And so, decisions about moderation have to at least get cleared by the lawyers. And you see what happened after the sex trafficking amendment. Craigslist, days before it was signed into law, got rid of its personal section because they said it's just too much risk. And that's going to--I mean, I think changes to Section 230--and we might decide it's a good thing.

PETHOKOUKIS: Were you surprised at that outcome?

KOSSEFF: No, no.

PETHOKOUKIS: Yeah.

KOSSEFF: I mean--

CITRON: We worked on it, like with different offices. It was depressing what came out of the sausage factory, like we tried.

KOSSEFF: Yeah, I mean, I--

CITRON: --What comes out of committee was depressing, and what was signed was depressing.

KOSSEFF: I testified in the House Judiciary Committee--

CITRON: --Yeah--

KOSSEFF: --in support of the limited exception for intentionally facilitating sex trafficking.

CITRON: Yeah.

KOSSEFF: What ended up--it's a standard that is--

CITRON: --No--

KOSSEFF: --yeah, you really can't comprehend it. So, the lawyers basically will just be risk-averse. So, I mean, I think that I'm definitely not opposed to Section 230 changes. I just think they need to be really, really carefully crafted and deliberate and not just sort of some legislative compromise that gets attached to an Appropriations bill right before the December recess. I mean, that's not what we want.

HARPER: That's everything these days.

KOSSEFF: Yes, exactly.

CITRON: And that's--so, FOSTA and SESTA is Jim's proof of concept, like your worry, Jim, is FOSTA and SESTA.

HARPER: It's been validated already, yeah.

CITRON: No, and I'm a Pollyanna, so I'm always engaged and happy to help offices. So, I'm not going to give up on the enterprise. But, that--FOSTA and SESTA--is what you're talking about, like--

PETHOKOUKIS: --I'm going to ask one more question, and then wanted to (INAUDIBLE) for them with a great panel, then I'm going to ask questions. So whether you're a Pollyanna, pessimist, be prepared. I think we'll bring mics around. So, I--so, if 230 was eliminated, what does that world look like?

Do we--again, do we still have--do we still have these platforms? Does it destroy their business models? Is it something--is it something radically different, or is it just a--what does that world look like if we did real harm in the effort of reforming to this provision?

KOSSEFF: So, I don't think we know for sure because for the entire modern internet, we've had Section 230. So, I mean, there are a bunch of different outcomes. Platforms could take the approach that, "Okay, well, the Common Law and First Amendment give me more protections if I don't do any moderation," which--I think most of us would say that's not a great outcome.

They could also become risk-averse and just say we're not going to allow user content because that just exposes us to too much risk. Or perhaps it will be somewhere in between. But, I can't say with any certainty what would happen because that would really be new territory for us.

PETHOKOUKIS: And perhaps because you would have thrown your computer out the window.

KOSSEFF: Yes, exactly.

PETHOKOUKIS: So, you would just not know what was going on on the internet.

KOSSEFF: Exactly.

HARPER: Brent Skorop and Jennifer Huddleston at the Mercatus Center have a good article on the common law developments that they saw coming along when 2030 was passed--a trend--because publishing has changed--a trend toward treating platforms as conduits, that aren't and can't be responsible for what appears on their sites.

So, that gives me confidence that the long-term outcome--I know it's debatable--but it gives me confidence that the long-term outcome would probably be good. We'd get a good result, where the economically efficient and free-speech, protective result would pertain.

But, in the short term, there would be a stampede against the platforms of litigation. If the repeal of 230 were to signal that the federal law is opposed to protections for liability, then that could actually undercut the proper common law development. So, I don't know how you get--I don't know how you get there from here. But if you ask the question in the abstract, what happens if 2030 goes away, I think common law and First Amendment protections for platforms would arrive at about the place where 2030 has gone.

PETHOKOUKIS: Over time, over time.

HARPER: Perhaps with some narrow tweaks so that the worst examples of egregious behavior that's supported by platforms would be impinged upon and would go away, so--

PETHOKOUKIS: --Lots (INAUDIBLE) go to questions.

CITRON: We can go--

PETHOKOUKIS: --We'll go to questions. Fantastic. All right, if you have a question, raise your hand, and we will send the mic over to you. I will start with that table right there, the gentleman with the laptop. If you care to say where you're from, feel free.

QUESTION: Yeah, Carl Szabo with NetChoice. James, you asked about the value of Section 230. Mike Niznik (SP) actually has a really good paper that came out, $440 billion over the next decade is the value. You asked about content moderation. We actually at NetChoice have a report coming out shortly that aggregates all the transparency reports from Facebook, Google, and Twitter. They removed in six months 5 billion accounts and posts, so there is active content moderation.

But, I do want to hit on something that you brought up at the end. What happens if we get rid of Section 230? And Section 230, Jeff, you point out in your book, goes to encourage content moderation. And 8chan, it doesn't really matter if they lose Section 230, right, because they don't engage in content moderation. Danielle, you brought up Grindr, which seems to not engage in a lot of content moderation, do you expect to see a rise in hate and offensive and terrorist content as platforms move away from the risky content moderation towards a, "Well, we achieve total immunity if we do nothing?"

CITRON: That's just not true, though. They don't risk it by engaging in content moderation. You're saying if we change Section 230?

QUESTION: Yeah.

CITRON: Is that--oh, so sorry. I just wanted to make sure I understood the premise of the question. So, we wipe out Section 230, you're saying? And then, we wipe out Section 230, and we live in a world which--prodigy. We're afraid of being treated as publishers. And so, we engage in no moderation--content moderation. And I think that's in part what Quinta Jurecic and I worried about in a paper that we wrote about FOSTA and SESTA, that we would have either both bad silincryptus (SP) of no moderation or too much moderation.

So, I share your concern, right, that we're going to end up looking like either 8chan--it's like the Wild West--or that it's family friendly--that it's just overly censored, just what we thought 25-whatever years ago.

PETHOKOUKIS: I'm jumping back in. I mean, do you think that (INAUDIBLE) companies, they would just love to be out of this business, they would love to be out of--

CITRON: --I don't (SP) think so--

PETHOKOUKIS: --They would love to be out of the figuring out what is hate speech, what is not hate speech?

CITRON: Spam? Like--oh, yeah, they would like Europe off their backs,

(LAUGHTER)

but that's not because of us. Does that make sense? Like the hate speech conversation, that is because of Europe. Truly that pressure is less coming from--

KOSSEFF: --But I would also just say that they would love to be out of this business, but they need to be in this business.

CITRON: Yeah, well--

KOSSEFF: --This is--this is a product that--and a service they're making a lot of money off of. They--this is part of the job.

HARPER: It should be said, at least once in this event, that the users out there are a little bit responsible, too.

CITRON: Yeah.

PETHOKOUKIS: We're crazy.

CITRON: Totally.

HARPER: When it comes to fake news, what ever happened to, "Don't believe everything you read," right?

CITRON: Oh, man, it's a bummer.

PETHOKOUKIS: Another question. On that side--you're very quiet over there, and I'll come--I'll get back to you. That table right there--right next to Mike. How convenient.

QUESTION: My name is Roger Cocceti (SP), and during the 1990s, I was the IBM executive responsible for worldwide internet policy and thus had a front-row seat in the development of Section 230. There was an important piece of the puzzle the panel hasn't discussed, and it leads me to think of what might be a blunderbuss way to deal with the issue.

One of the elements that went into the assumptions that we all made at that time was that the future would be very much like the past. And most of us had in mind, at the time 230 was approved, computer bulletin boards. That's what we thought of as content. How could a--and some day most--the thinking was that some day there would be a 100 million people on the internet, and there would be 100,000 websites.

And everyone really assumed that there would be Facebook in the future, in fact there would be thousands of Facebooks, and none of them would have more than like 2 percent market share. And everyone assumed there would be a Google in the future, in fact there would be hundreds of Googles, and none of them would have more than 1 percent market share. There would be a distributed system like the internet itself is distributed. So, there was never any expectation of enormity that we see today.

PETHOKOUKIS: And your question, sir?

QUESTION: And the question is, perhaps that assumption that went into thinking--and because of that, it was assumed that the internet was going to be made up of thousands and thousands of small businesses that could never possibly monitor 100 million people posting on their bulletin boards.

The question, then, is if we--and I realize this is a blunderbuss solution--but think about it for a moment. Suppose we went as far as to say any network that has a billion users or a market value of a trillion dollars is by definition a publisher with the same rights and duty to care that the Northwest Current and the Georgetowner Today have when they post want ads--or they have to look at it and make a judgment. And at that scale, you are a publisher, and no gray area. You have the same responsibility that a call-in radio program or a neighborhood newspaper has of duty of care when you reach that size.

PETHOKOUKIS: All right. Do you want to jump in on that one?

HARPER: I might think too abstractly about most things, but I have a hard time thinking that justice changes--the terms of justice in the world change--if the size of your network goes above 999,999,999. So, I want--I want the rules to be rooted in justice and not administrative stuff that keeps the lawyers working.

Either it's--either there's--either you're doing it right, or you're doing it wrong. There's reasonable, and there's unreasonable, and the law should hew as closely as possible to that, not, "You've got to be reasonable once you've reached a certain threshold of users or market capitalization," or whatever the case may be.

So, that type of rule exists all over the place. And you see lots of small businesses staying small, so they don't have to provide health insurance to their employees. And I don't want more of that, not in this area.

PETHOKOUKIS: All right, unless--gentleman right--right in front of me.

QUESTION: Good morning. Thank you for doing this. I'm Jeff Jarvis from the Newmark School of Journalism at CUNY. And I'm also a member of a--pardon for the long title--Transatlantic Working Group on Content Moderation and Freedom of Expression organized by Susan Ness sitting two people from the left of me.

And I've learned a lot. I just want to just throw two quick ideas out to get your response. One from that group that I've learned is that maybe we should concentrate not on content but on behaviors. You're trying to get rid of behaviors, and that's a different--that's what law does. And there's a suggestion coming from one member of the group that there ought to be national internet courts where matters of legality should go to a court where we negotiate legal norms in public with due process.

And in terms of the legal but irritating--which is what the UK wants to go after--now we have Facebook's oversight board, where they're trying to establish that. And we'll see how that goes. So, I wonder about your views of these kinds of efforts to, in essence, come up with new common law through different paths as we negotiate this very new landscape.

PETHOKOUKIS: Danielle, you've written about this quite a bit.

CITRON: Yeah. No, in 2014 in my book, Hate Crimes in Cyberspace, I argue that we should--a company should engage in what I call a different venue--technological due process--that they should be transparent and accountable for their content moderation practices, that is--it could be as a matter of law--but that they should.

And I'm not sure if I see--and maybe Jeff and Jim can join me on this--the difference, conduct and speech, the line is really blurry. And so, the difference between content and conduct, yes, it's true, I think we should be more careful to realize that some speech actually is tantamount to conduct in that stalking, harassment, workplace sexual harassment, we can make--there are some moments where we can say, that's truly like a bludgeon, an instrument rather than conveying a message or a viewpoint.

But, largely it's really hard. So, I'm not sure if that would be--I feel like I have my speech friends with me here--that would be--conduct and speech are one and the same. I'm going to channel Katy McKinnon here a little bit, like they are--a lot of conduct is expressive and vice versa.

HARPER: Yeah, but I don't want to talk about that.

CITRON: No, no, you talk about what you want to talk about. Yeah.

PETHOKOUKIS: Free speech.

CITRON: Right.

HARPER: A national internet court.

CITRON: Oh, yeah.

HARPER: It sounds like a thing you'll get if you just wait around for a couple years, and the older judges move out, and the younger judges move in. So, I don't know about a specialized court for this. And I actually want to challenge--because you mentioned it a second time now--the idea that companies should be providing due process and transparency. I'm a big, big fan of transparency.

CITRON: And not (INAUDIBLE)

HARPER: --In the governmental context, right.

CITRON: But, just that we could require--

HARPER: --But true transparency in your content moderation would be a huge gift to your adversary because over on 4chan--or is it 8chan now, I'm a fuddy-duddy, I think of 4chan--they would go and figure out how to game the rules you've just published--

CITRON: --Yeah, but just say we can't--

HARPER: --And do the thing that falls right on the line between the two.

CITRON: That's nonsense, no.

HARPER: It is not nonsense.

CITRON: It's nonsense.

HARPER: They work hard, smart people--

CITRON: --Of course--

HARPER: --unfortunately socially maladapted smart people--

CITRON: --platforms are smart, too. You can't game us--

HARPER: --working very hard to game published--published rules. That's a gift, I think, to them.

CITRON: That's law.

HARPER: Right.

CITRON: Like so you're saying we shouldn't have law that's published, and we can game?

HARPER: No, no, but it's gameable, and you have to have laws that are--are--that don't have too many nooks and crannies because people will game them rather than just live right.

KOSSEFF: So, I would say there has to be more transparency than there is right now. And we're getting better. I think today compared to three or four years ago, there is much more transparency, but we have a long way to go. And this is one thing that I really stress to the tech companies, is that Section 230 is not a constitutional right.

This is something that Congress has provided. And there are some people who will say Section 230 isn't a benefit to the tech companies, and I think that's nonsense. Of course, it's a benefit to the tech companies. It's a benefit to the public as well for free speech platforms. But, tech companies do receive--I mean, they have been able to structure business models around this.

And I have no problem with some sort of transparency basically being a premise of Section 230 because we need to have a better idea of what's going on. We haven't, and now you see what's going on now with the debate, which is chaotic, so I--

PETHOKOUKIS: --Where is the transparency--so when someone--an accountant gets suspended. It's not a mystery. You're like, "Oh, that makes sense, I get why that happened." And the person should have that kind of expectation if they engage in that behavior. They will understand it's a likely result.

KOSSEFF: I think that--and I think that can maybe help improve user behavior compared to where it is now but also more transparency about the broader policies. I mean, every--the platforms have policies posted, but they are fairly broad. And I think getting more specificity as to how the decisions are made, I see that as being a benefit overall.

PETHOKOUKIS: Shorter and clearer policies. The group over here--reluctant to ask a question, but--one straight and then sort of rudely pointing with my red pen right there.

QUESTION: Elizabeth Banker. I'm with Internet Association. I have a question about Professor Citron's proposal. As many commentators have noted, one of the advantages of Section 230 is that it does allow companies that are sued to get rid of the cases fairly quickly through a motion to dismiss, asserting the 230 immunity.

It sounds like your proposal would require litigation before being able to get to that stage. And I'm just wondering about the impact on smaller companies. We did talk about how, without Section 230, the bigger companies would have the resources to do more litigation while smaller companies wouldn't necessarily have the same resources. So, is there a way that your idea kind of takes into account that small business impact?

CITRON: So, reasonableness itself would. What is reasonable is different from a small--but it doesn't address your excellent point about the cost of litigation, right? What's reasonable we can adjudicate, and it would be very different from what's reasonable for small than--versus big, right?

And it's true that there would be costs. At the same time, we shouldn't forget that there are costs of the current system. There's no expense. There is dismissals. And what happens is we lose a lot. We lose a lot in terms of speech of victims who go offline. We have a lot of harm that is now externalized and borne only by individuals and not by the revenge porn operator.

So, I guess what I would say is I recognize that that would be true, would be more challenging and expensive for the small company to face litigation than it would Facebook and even if it cashes out that you have less onerous rules for small than big, that there would be the expense, of course. You might have more censorship creep and collateral censorship for the small versus the big because they can't litigate.

At the same time, some of those small actors are the folks running revenge porn sites. And so, I think we can't overlook that there are meaningful trade-offs, and it's not all trade-offs in speech in one direction, which is just that poor provider, right? There is also a lot of trade-offs for victims who--without any change they will be driven offline.

PETHOKOUKIS: A question over here, maybe the gentleman right directly--

QUESTION: --Hi, thank you. I just wanted to pry into something Jim brought up at the end that I think is a really important point. And I was wondering kind of what the panel would think about this. The question posed at today's event is, should we reform Section 230? And I think that there's two halves to that, right? We have our academic question of, well, is there possible ways that 230 can be improved? And then, there's the other side, which is, should we kick off that process here in D.C. and in Congress?

And I think there seems to be complete agreement on the panel that 230 has been very beneficial--is very important to the internet that we all enjoy today. So, my fairly quick question is, with Congress not necessarily being trusted with a lot of tech policy--or even policy more generally to get things through in a way that really gives us what we want--would you kick off that process? Would you take that risk that potentially Congress could undermine Section 230 fatally just to get through potentially reforms that you see as beneficial?

KOSSEFF: I mean, we have Article 1, which pretty much says they have to. I mean, they are the ones who are charged with it. And I think looking at it is one thing. And, I mean, one of the jobs of Congress is to look at the laws that they've passed. So, I think just--I would agree there are some challenges that Congress has with understanding technology, and I'll just be as broad a possible in saying that. But, that's not a reason to not look at laws. I think there are efforts to revive OTA, for example, which would help inform that and is absolutely essential when we're dealing with--

HARPER: --The Office of Technology Assessment--

KOSSEFF: --Yes. Yeah, which basically was Congress's in-house technology think tank. And that sort of thing--so, yeah, I think Congress has to look at laws. Whether they should do anything is something different. I'd like my commission to help inform that.

CITRON: Yeah.

KOSSEFF: But, yeah, I mean, we have no other choice.

HARPER: Your question, I think, helps--helps show that we're kind of talking about two different types of governmental bodies. Do we trust the Legislature, or do we trust the Judiciary more? The talk of the common law is over on the judiciary side. It might be handled better there. No question that the world of litigation could be reformed quite a bit itself, so the costs that the earlier question referred to are serious and not to be forgotten.

Maybe familiarity breeds contempt, but I worked in Congress, and I have been a Congress watcher for a lot of years, and I don't think I would try to run anything through there. We're much better off keeping 230 where it is and letting case by case perhaps trim it back where appropriate.

PETHOKOUKIS: We have time for only one more question. It needs to be concise, powerful--so, if you're going to raise your hand--if you raise your hand, there's going to be a--okay, all right, this is a biggie. Wait for the mic.

HARPER: Wait for the mic.

CITRON: Yeah.

HARPER: Everybody needs to hear you.

QUESTION: Will Duffield, Cato Institute. These private moderation systems that these platforms manage are essentially private legal systems, and in order for them to work--to get buy-in--they need to be legitimate in someone's eyes. In whose eyes should they attempt to legitimate themselves--users, states, the population at large? What renders these private governance systems legitimate or not?

HARPER: The market.

CITRON: Yeah.

HARPER: Cato Institute, I had to--you teed it right up.

CITRON: Crazy response.

PETHOKOUKIS: You do not know the answer to that question.

HARPER: But, the question allows me to put an important gloss on what I said about transparency. Transparency I do think would be a gift to people who are trying to game your system. But, if transparency will give your users and your governmental overseers confidence that what you are doing is right, then, okay, go ahead. But, you're going to have problems with your--with your adversaries because of that transparency, too.

PETHOKOUKIS: All right. I think that will have to be it. All-star panel, all-star audience, thank you very much for coming.

urn:contentItem:5G4P-N4X1-JB20-G35W-00000-00American Express Co at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final2015-05-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexis052815a5689559.759American Express Co at Sanford C Bernstein Strategic Decisions Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ken Chenault

American Express- Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

* Kevin St. Pierre

Sanford C Bernstein - Analyst

Presentation

KEVIN ST. PIERRE, ANALYST, SANFORD C BERNSTEIN: All right, I think we will get started. Good morning everyone. I'm Kevin St. Pierre. I cover consumer finance and mid-cap banks for Bernstein. I'm pleased to have with us today Ken Chenault, Chairman and CEO of American ExpressI'm sure most of you know. Ken, thank you very much for joining us. So, the plan is I'll moderate a discussion for about 30 minutes or so with Ken covering the company's strategic vision and industry controversies and then I'll start mixing in some questions from the audience. So, as questions arise, please fill out the cards and we'll be going around collecting them.

So, Ken maybe we could start out with one of the big issues that's on investors' minds and right before this presentation in this room was Citiand talking about the Costco relationship and how they felt it was going to be ROA, ROE accretive for them. Maybe you could talk to us a bit about the decision to let that relationship and you've said that they were looking for a credit utility, but maybe update us and give us your view on that.

KEN CHENAULT, CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, AMERICAN EXPRESS: Sure. I think what's important first is to put in a little bit of context how we think about the business, what we were trying to do. And so around 15 to 18 months ago, I thought it was very important that we get some visibility of what was happening in the Co-Brand space, because clearly the Co-Brand environment was not going to get more benign. It has certainly become more competitive. And my view was whether than wait until the agreement was up, in fact was to negotiate with a range of major Co-Brand partners that we had like Delta, like Starwood, like Cathay Pacific, Iberia and renew early, so we would have visibility on what we would do in the Co-Brand space.

And also very importantly because we have a range of opportunities in our proprietary businesses and in our GNS business, that we achieve very good returns. And so, it was critical that we have that type of perspective, so we approach Costco proactively and said that we wanted to negotiate early with them. What I would point out is, with every other Co-Brand partner, Delta, Starwood, British Airways, Cathay Pacific, Iberia; we were able to sign them. With Costco, what became very clear as I've said pretty consistently, is their position to change to that they were focused more on a credit utility, and I think what's that's very critical with American Expressis that we are very focused on delivering differentiated value. And if you look at the fact and anyone who understands Costco knows that they are frequently negotiating with their suppliers. We had a 16-year agreement with Costco and that 16-year agreement was really based on the creativity, the innovation, the differentiation that we brought to Costco, and I am frankly very proud about what we delivered to Costco over those 16 years.

But the reality is their priority is the exchange, which they are certainly entitled to change their priorities. But, I think what's very, very important is that our business model is really built on offering differentiated products and services, and obviously we're a disciplined buyer, and we want to make sure that we are in relationships and partnerships in businesses where we can deliver appropriate shareholder returns over the moderate to long term. And as I've been very, very clear, the numbers just did not add up.

What was also important is there were certain terms in the contract that would have been more restrictive on us. There were certain terms in the contract from a credit standpoint that I did not think would be appropriate relative to our economics and our risk profile. And I think what is critical is that we had the opportunity, even though we knew there would be some short-term pain that we knew we had a range of growth initiatives that had a long runway for growth that would deliver better economics for our shareholders. Now I think what is critical here is that I think as a number of you know, and I know Ajay Banga spoke today, and made this point and his CFO made this point several weeks ago is I think they're also a disciplined buyer, and what his CFO said, I don't know exactly what Ajay said, but what I understand is that they were very challenged from a shareholder standpoint to make the economics work.

And so at the end of the day as a disciplined buyer, I don't think you do deals where you can't make money over the moderate long term, and I don't think you do deals where you reallocate your funding sources to a situation in the very long-term, where you're not going to be able to generate the appropriate level of the economics, particularly when you have a wide range of alternatives to generate that growth. The other point that I would make is that we were able to demonstrate with the signing of Charles Schwab that we have the capacity to do Co-Brand deals, they're going to be a range as you know of Co-Brand deals that will be coming up over the next 12 to 18 months. I think it's very positive that we have visibility and we understand where we stand with our existing Co-Brand partners that we were able to renew those deals except for Costco.

And so what I would say is that, I think that we delivered and raised the bar each year in the 16 years with Costco, but I don't believe in doing a deal that is not going to generate appropriate economic returns for our shareholders in the moderate long term. And I also feel that we have a range of opportunities that will allow us to grow and achieve the appropriate financial objectives for our company. And the other thing that I think is critical as a result of not having the Costco deal; it also allows us to do a range of partnerships with other retailers, not just Co-Brand, but other types of marketing partnerships as we go forward.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: So the follow-up question that I get from investors is, isn't this -- is Costco a one-off, is it a unique situation or isn't this indicative of a trend that's likely to continue perhaps snowball with retailers, merchants looking for better terms for themselves, and won't that continue to be a trend and invite into profitability as we go forward?

KEN CHENAULT: Look, I think the reality is that we've been very clear that the Co-Brand space has become more competitive. As I said earlier, we were able to negotiate renewals with all of the Co-Brand partners that I listed at appropriate economic terms that I think are in the strong interest of our shareholders. And I think it really depends on the Co-Brand partner, and if someone in fact, which is always the case, is just focused on price alone.

I think, it might be useful just a little bit of history on Costcos starting off from the beginning is, we called on Costco for several years before we actually did a deal with them; and it's very simple what they said to us, which was basically a cost play is, the discount rate is too high. And then we said, look, we're going to change our approach and I think this was creative when we said at that time to the CEO Jim Sinegal, what are your most important levers that you want to pull in your business? And he said, I want to retain warehouse club memberships and want to gain more warehouse club memberships. I said what if we could put together a business proposition that would allow you to gain more warehouse club memberships, and in fact increase your retention level? And so we structured a very innovative deal.

And so I think what's incumbent upon us, which is true in the overall marketplace is to come up with creative ideas that offer a differentiated model that allow us to generate attractive ideas. Now, the reality is someone can always at a point of time say; I, in fact, want to get the money in the short term. The question is going to be what happens over the moderate to long term, and the ability of the provider to in fact continue to differentiate the product.

And what we've seen in some Co-Brand situations where it's just about the money is the sustainability has really not been there. And so what we are focused on is moderate to long term. And I think that we'll continue to selectively go after Co-Brands. That was our position before that is our position now. We said we didn't want to do hundreds of Co-Brands; we wanted to do selective Co-Brands. That's why I feel very good about the Charles Schwab Co-Brand.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Stepping up from Co-Brand, card issuance consumer cards in general, what do you say to people who question the sustainability over profitability when you're competing against other issuers who are earning much lower returns are satisfied happy with much lower returns than American Express? How are you able to maintain your profitability when you're competing against others who can accept lower?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, so here's our -- I'd answer that in several ways. First, I think it's really positive. Last quarter, we had a 29% ROE. Our target is a 25% ROE. I'm not embarrassed about that. I think that's good. I think that gives us a range of optionality in our business. I'm glad we have a range of businesses with growth opportunities that generate attractive returns. But as I have been very, very clear, our floor is not -- we're not going to do a deal unless it generates 25% ROE, what I would say is it gives us a range of flexibility. Now, I don't want to do things that lose money, but I want to be very, very clear that we're going to do deals that are in the moderate-to-long term interest of our company even though some of those deals maybe below and substantially below a 25% ROE. However, the target of a 25%. We believe, when we look at the range of businesses we are in, the growth opportunities, that we can achieve that. So I don't see that as a disadvantage; and as I said before, with Costco the numbers did not add up, and I don't really see that as the issue for us in my view is, I want to continue to grow in businesses that generate very attractive returns.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Shifting away from the industry competition, one topic that you've highlighted consistently over the past few years is the impact of digitization on the payments business. How will the convergence of online and offline commerce play out over the next few years and what role will American Expressplay?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, I think one of the most profound developments, not just in payments and commerce, but in a range of industries is the convergence of online and offline. And I think what's very, very important is that American ExpressI think is better positioned in the digital transformation and will be even more relevant, because we have the largest integrated payments platform in the world.

Now what's critical about that is that if you go through our business we in fact have relationships with millions of end user card members. We have relationships with millions of merchants. If we look at what's happening in commerce and with digital companies and payments companies, talk about convergence of online, offline, there is an increase in convergence between commerce and payments of commerce companies that are getting involved in aspects of payments and payments companies getting involved in aspects of commerce. But what's central to that is the information and the data. And so this close loop that we talk about of information of the end user, information from the merchant, and understanding of what purchases took place online and offline, what time those purchases were made, become increasingly important.

And so you find a number of digital companies trying to figure out ways that they're going to have access to online information and to offline information, as well as online information because that becomes very, very important going forward. So I think having that opportunity -- I think what's also critical is that if you look at what we've done over the years, American Expresswas the first company to securely connect a card member's account to a social media platform as we did with Foursquare, as we are doing with Twitter, as we've done with Facebook. I think the deals we've done with Uber, the deals we've done with Amazon and Shop with Points. So I think what is very, very important is that convergence is changing.

Now there are a few other points I'd make from a broad industry perspective is Forrester Research, I believe -- I think I've got this number close to right says that 8% of retail spending is online, 30% of that is mobile; projected to grow by 2018 to 11%. But, I think there is a very important point that people miss. What's also projected is that 75% of the retail sales that are offline will be web enabled, meaning they will touch at some point in the commerce journey with a digital device. That means it's very important that American Expressis where our customers are. And so the opportunity impact with an integrated payments platform to give people the opportunity to connect. And then one of the capability we have is our credit authorizations platform, which actually integrates the data from the end user customer and the merchant. So, we literally when you're using your card, we actually are running a model on -- every time you use your card what's the level of spending that you can do and that's personalized. Well, we're also able to use that close loop information for the environment that we're in to manage our credit or frauds. Our fraud rates are 50% lower than Visa and MasterCard to provide targeted marketing offers. So, I think that this integrated payments platform is going to be very, very important going forward. And I think it's critical that they're going to be some payment companies that are going to stay in the payments space, and I think they run a risk if they don't understand the value that customers are looking for that there are commerce companies that can provide certain types of value that are similar to payments companies and vice versa going forward.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: At the onset of the mobile revolution, there were some who feared that the big tech companies whether it's Apple, Google, Samsung would seek to disintermediate the credit card, and that's sort of given way that this cautious optimism as they've partnered with the card issuers essentially, there are still some who fear that over time, those companies will seek a greater piece of the economics, what do you say to that.

KEN CHENAULT: Look, I think it's always prudent to be very focused on what are all the different scenarios. But I'd remind you wasn't that long ago, five years or six years ago, where the questions I would get is would mobile wallets disintermediate payment networks. That was the view; that was a question at these types of meetings that I would get constantly. What's happened is that in fact there is an understanding that the payments infrastructure to people who really want to get involved in credit and in fraud, it is complex and I think what is important for Apple and important in general.

As I said before we're agnostic relative to form factor. I don't care if plastic goes away. That's not what the relevant point is. If you look at the Apple Wallet, which I'm excited about Apple, I'm excited about what we're doing. I'm excited about the implementation of Apple, even though it's in its early stages what is very critical and it's one of the signposts, that I think you want to look at as you see companies navigate through this digital transformation, is what are some of the core attributes that have to be retained. For us, it's the closed loop. And so the Apple Wallet really acts as a pass-through wallet, where I have the direct relationship with the merchant and the end-user customer, and my closed loop information is preserved.

And I think you will see in any deals that we do, that's what you should look for. When you see announcements of different mobile wallets coming out is our closed loop being preserved, are we having direct relationships with the end user, because that becomes very, very important, that direct relationship because that gives us the continuing ability to differentiate our products and services.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Beyond technology, some of the new initiatives that you've launched, a common theme is the concept of AmEx being a more inclusive brand with things like every day serving and plenty, maybe you could describe some what you're seeing in some of those initiatives and have you been successful in changing the perception of your brand?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, I think what's very, very important just from a little bit of a history lesson over a 165 years, and it's something I remind people in the Company is American Expressstarted off as freight forwarding company. And the reality is our Travelers Cheque business did not have any income requirement at all. The attributes that really have driven our brand and I think will be, as I said even more relevant in this digital transformation, very importantly our trust, security and service. So, if we think right now about all that's going on with personal information and financial data, I think the trust that American Expresshas built in the marketplace, and the infrastructure and the capabilities we have in the end-to-end process give us a major advantage.

What we're seeing is increasing levels of digital engagement from younger customers in our products and services. AmEx every day that we launched in March 2014, last year alone was 10% of our new card acquisitions. As I said, what we've been able to do with Uber, what we've been able to do with Facebook, our philosophy is that we want to be where our card members want to be.

As we've seen with Serve, but what's important there is that 44% of those customers are under 35, and what we've seen in our brand research is our brand value has actually increased year-over-year as you look at -- into brand and other brand valuation sources, and I think it was two years ago we had John Hayes, our Chief Marketing Officer, at an investor presentation go through certain measurements and how the brand is valued. And one of things we saw is that when AmEx Card Members who were aware of Serve or Bluebird, they actually had a 30% higher view of the brand than those who didn't.

And I think part of it goes to two or three reasons. One is, I think people are turned on by innovation that they see in the marketplace. We're doing a lot of digital innovation in the marketplace. And second, I think that they like to be affiliated with a company and a brand that stand for something. So our core attributes, I think they like, but the fact that we're offering products to people who traditionally have not had access to those products has been very helpful to our brand building.

And the other point, I would make is that we have seen improvements from a brand inventory standpoint in our higher-end products. So, if we look at Platinum, we have a 70% share of wallet with our Platinum card members, 55% share of wallet with our gold card members. So, I think that what's critical in a brand, is you've got to transform and transition the brand. When a brand is not relevant it's when in fact the value proposition that you're offering the specific customer segment is not relevant, but what we found is that when we offer a product that has the right rationale value proposition coupled with the emotional attributes of our brand, it's very powerful.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Maybe we could step up to some of the growth targets, the financial targets. You've maintained your long-term on-average over time 12% to 15% EPS growth target, and getting back to that in 2017. Can you walk us through the drivers of that, and help what makes you confident you can get there?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, so let me first start, again with the foundation one, I think of having the largest integrated global payments platform helps us tremendously. And then, the foundation that we have to build on, if we look at leadership in terms of billings, which I think that's the ultimate output is where the billings, that you're able to drive. We're the number one issuer in terms of consumer. We're the number one issuer in terms of small business. We're the number one issuer in corporate payments. We represent, we have clients 63% of the Fortune 500. We're the number one merchant that we acquire, the billings volume. So we're number one there. We're the number one US Company from an international billings standpoint. So, I think we're starting off with a very strong foundation.

Now what's critical if you look at the three core drivers for growth for us, and I'll go through some of the growth opportunities that we have is obviously we want to continue to grow revenues through a range of very diverse opportunities. We need to continue the improvements, and I've been very pleased with what we've done in operating expense leverage over the last few years. Our capital strength is very strong along with our share buybacks, and so what I have emphasized is that the most important financial metric, Kevin, to your point is the 12% to 15% earnings per share.

Now just to give you some examples of different opportunities is we are fortunate that across the entire portfolio. We are in businesses that have a long runway for growth; albeit, we've got competition in those businesses at varying levels, and those businesses also can generate very strong returns for our shareholders. If you think about small business for example, which we have been in for decades and are clearly the leader, $4.8 trillion in spending only and small business -- so I can define it for people is $10 million in revenues and below.

10% of that $4.8 trillion is on plastic, so that's a long runway for growth. We've been in this business for a while. That's a business that in fact has over the last several years performed well from a billings growth standpoint and a revenue growth standpoint. Middle market is a very attractive business and that covers a category of $10 million, up to $500 million and the penetration level there is also very low.

With both small business and middle market, we've invested more in -- we have focused not only in the US but expanding in a variety of international markets and we see that as a very strong opportunity. I think what we're doing in merchant acceptance with OptBlue is going to benefit all of our card products and that's really a program where we have worked with third parties and we've given them the pricing and other terms and we've gotten off to a great start 2014.

Through OptBlue we brought in 400,000 merchants, and what we said is that starting in 2015, each year we would expect to bring in 500 -- between 500,000 to 800,000 small merchants going forward. So, we're feeling good about what that will do for growth both of the reality of welcome acceptance and also the perception of coverage.

I think in consumer, you'll see over the next few months, changes that we're making to the value proposition, and I think we'll improve it. I think we are very pleased with AmEx every day. We're making improvements in Platinum, Centurion, Gold, GNS our bank partnership business has been one of our fastest growing businesses over the last decade. And I think we're still in the early stages. I think that has a very long runway for growth. International, we have seen in 11 of our key markets, we've grown in all those markets, and in eight of those 11, we've grown faster than the market. So, I want to emphasize, we've done this in a situation of strong competition, but I think we have a range of opportunities, Serve is in its early stages.

There was a Nielsen report I think that came out prepaid is still relatively small for the industry overall, but had growth, I think they said today of 200%. We've had growth in the last year or two, 300% in billings early days. So I don't want to overhype it. Loyalty Partner, I think is a very exciting business for us and gets back to this convergence between payments and commerce, so the way loyalty works is that our loyalty coalition program in international, we call payback, we have a range of what we call founding sponsors, and you want to get large companies in everyday spending categories.

We manage the platform, we get fees on that platform, we provide insights, we provide more business for merchants who use it and what's very important is any payment product can be used. Cash, checks, MasterCard, Visa, AmEx, it's a closed loop. It has SKU level data, and we operate in five markets around the world. We just launched it very recently in the last month and a half in the US, it is early stages, but you had the CFO of Macy's, who said in the first week of Plenti they had 2 million enrollees, which far exceeded the objectives that they had set. So again, very, very early stages, but I think we have the balance between the existing businesses in the new.

Now, I think what's also important is that, we'll just go back to presentation that I made two years ago when I went through a range of scenarios. They basically said could we achieve 12% to 15% growth without achieving 8% revenue growth, and there were a lot of variables in there that we went through, but I think they were reasonable. If we then looked at the reality of how we have performed, it actually played out pretty close to those scenarios, and we were able with a range of 4% to 6% revenue growth over the last four years to be within the range of 12% to 15%, and I could tell you, I think in this economic environment, which has been slow to moderate growth. 4% to 6% revenue growth is pretty darn good when you compare it to the S&P 500 and the Dow.

And so I think we have the growth initiatives that I talked about, I think you have seen different levers, and so this is not me speculating, which I did two years ago of here's how some different scenarios could play out. You actually saw how we dealt with those different levers, and what we were able to achieve. So I think what's critical is I have a firm belief in the growth initiatives that we put in place, that it will allow us to generate appropriate revenue growth. I have confidence that we're going to be able to continue to achieve the operating leverage. And third, I think the capital strength that we have along with the share buybacks give us the opportunity to achieve that 12% to 15%. So that's the pathway.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: I like that presentation from two years ago. I tweaked it a bit and said all I AmEx to do is turn the 643, I am a big baseball fan. So, if you can get 6% revenue growth, control expenses at 4% annual growth, 3% annual share repurchase, I get you to 14%. So, just turn the 643.

KEN CHENAULT: I sort of like that. It has a nice ring in.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: I'm going to start mixing in some of the questions from the audience. So there's and I'm going to try and organize them as best I can, but couple of questions on the potential sale of the Costco portfolio, and what will be done with the proceeds, will that be buybacks? In the past we've seen where there have been some gains and again reinvested, what would be the plan for the proceeds to the Costco portfolio?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, it's premature. I mean, one thing I actually should have said, which I think you all know is that the new Costco deal is subject to Citibuying the portfolio that has to happen. So that is a very important assumption. Obviously, we can't go into a lot of detail or any detail on what's happening in the conversations that we're having. But what I can say Kevin and this would go -- let me make a broader point is we recognize what the reset that we're doing this year where we're going to be in 2016 and then as we said, our objective is to get back to 12% to 15% growth.

What I would say to people is that you've really got to focus on the underlying business performance. So you need to focus on the metrics that you have historically focused on. We need to do our best in fact to clarify for you how the underlying business is performing excluding some of the discrete items like the Costco, the fact that we signed other Co-Brands that we've talked about; FX, and then the incremental investments that we're making in growth. So we will need to do that, but from a contractual standpoint, I really cannot share what's going on in the conversations we're having except to say that what's fundamental to the deal is that the portfolio has to be sold for the deal to happen. And that's critical to understand our view is that I think we have demonstrated a willingness both to invest in those growth opportunities, I think, I've outlined a range of growth opportunities out there. But I don't think I can speculate on what's going to happen with the portfolio. So, I wish I could say more but I can't.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Several other questions about something else you might not be able to say a lot about, but the DOJ case and an update where we are in the process?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, I can't say a lot except to say I think as many of you know, we have begun the appeal process on this day. I think we have a strong case. The only thing I can say as with any situation, we are prepared for different scenarios. But it wouldn't be appropriate for me to go into details or give further comment there.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Couple of questions. You alluded to this, but maybe you can either re-answer or give a little more information. Couple questions saying are you diluting the brand right by going down market, are you concerned about brand erosion of your high-end customers?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes -- you know what, just to go back, I think what's very important is in the 1990s, I put together three operating principles that Harvey Golub, the then CEO adopted for the entire company. And these are principles that I really adhere to and that is we want to provide superior value to the customers and clients we serve.

Second, we want to do it in a way that will allow us to achieve best-in-class economics and third, everything we do must support and enhance the brand. And I view myself as in fact the brand steward of the Company. And the reality is that we are not going to do anything to dilute the brand. But, I go back to the fact that it's something that this company is very, very focused on and one of the ways this brand was built -- one of the businesses that was built on was a Travelers Cheque product that has had no income requirement that was available to everyone. But because of the service, because of the trust, because of the value proposition that enabled us to in fact enter into the card business with the level of trust and commitment to service.

And what we've seen is that when we can construct a value proposition that is meaningful to customers that the brand is enhanced. When that value proposition is in fact not meaningful to customers and let's not go back to foreign time when we embarked on a very ill-advised financial supermarket strategy. It wasn't that those businesses were horrible businesses, but the question is that those businesses enhanced the brand? There we did see some brand dilution and not just for economic reasons but for brand reasons and for strategic focus reasons, we divested out of those businesses.

And I think now we're a more focused competitor, but the other point that I think is critical to understand with the digital transformation is that scale has been redefined and it is important that you are relevant to a range of customer segments, but in that relevance, I can assure you that we're very focused on making sure we have an alignment of the value proposition with the principles and the attributes of our brand. We follow brand value very consistently and we in fact have seen improvement in the brand value not dilution and that's something that we don't take for granted, but I'm confident that will be our continued focus.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Few questions about the merchant discount rate and the sort of steady erosion or steady decline, put it that way, I know there's some mix and some competitive forces there, but maybe if you could characterize what inning we're in, in terms of the merchant discount rate declining, do we see that stabilize over the next few years?

KEN CHENAULT: I think the reality is you've got a number of forces. I mean you've got regulatory forces. I mean what's happening in Europe, what's happening in other parts of the world, what's happening in the US. There's clearly going to be impacts on the overall discount rate, what our job is and I think really the focus needs to be on value as well as price.

And one of the points that I think is really critical and goes with what we are trying to do with our business portfolio is we bring a higher spending card member to our merchants because of the breadth and depth of the most diverse portfolio in the industry. And our merchants still find that compelling, and it's our job to prove that value and our value to both merchants and card members every day. And so I am not going to sit here and predict what's going to happen to the discount rate over time.

The reality is, I think people have been saying really over the last two decades, in most cases that the discount rate would move down a lot faster than it actually has. So I think we'll have to see what happens there, but what's most important for us is that we are demonstrating the value that we can provide to merchants and the fact that spending on our cards is three to four times that of MasterCard and Visa. I think it is very, very important and that's something that we'll continue to demonstrate.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Couple of related questions here at the Berkshire Hathaway meeting Charlie Munger characterized returns of AmEx is coming down permanently versus the past due to competition; another question saying what are you doing to make your mode wider and deeper?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, I think what's important because I was actually at that meeting. Warren Buffett asked if I would come because it was their 50th Anniversary and obviously we're a big holding of Berkshire Hathaway. And my recollection and I have been in all the forums Charlie has spoken at is the mode as strong as it once was. And I think that was a reference to a question on Costco and the competition that's out there.

What we're doing to continue to strengthen the mode is to leverage this integrated payments platform that we have and the data and the information and the focus on leveraging those assets in our digital transformation so that we can provide increased value both in spending and insights and improve performance in more business, the merchants more personalized value. If we've looked at what we've done for example with our membership rewards program, the reality is we have a mobile app where you basically can access those points for almost any purchase.

So the way to build the mode is in fact to reinforce what are the fundamental advantages and the fundamental advantages are the fact that the brand really stands for something, Trust security and service, that's something that Warren really is aligned with. Second is the closed loop. That's really critical and to continue to innovate and I think we're doing that with the closed loop. And then, in fact to make sure that we are providing differentiated value propositions and that's why I go back to your first question that we have to make sure that we are working on businesses that will differentiate our model and that we're not just so coming to becoming a credit utility.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Great. I think we have time for one more. Question about Costco retention. Maybe you could describe the efforts you are going through to try and retain some of that Costco spend and anything you can share with us about initial success?

KEN CHENAULT: Yes, so Kevin, what I would say here are two things. One, I can't go into specifics obviously for competitive reasons. I've outlined what our tactical plans are. But we're very focused on things we need to do to retain the spend, and as we've said 70% of the spend in Costco in the US is outside.

I would say Canada is a very different situation because you didn't have a sale of a portfolio in Canada and there are clear differences there. As we've said over the last few months, we've been encouraged by what's happened in Canada. But I think it would be wrong to extrapolate what happened in Canada exactly to what's going on in the US because there are more uncertainties relative to what's going to happen with the overall portfolio.

What I would emphasize is I go back to the fundamental reason why we decided not to renew with Costco and that's because we have the range of opportunities across the business overall that will generate growth and that is the really important point that Costco is not the "be all and end all" of the company, and the reality is that we would not have decided to discontinue our relationship with Costco if in fact we said we don't have better alternatives. But the point is we had better alternatives and so the focus very much needs to be on, okay, prove it to us that's absolutely the appropriate that you're growing in the businesses that you've identified and that the call you've made is the right call in the moderate term, because that's really the basis of our action.

So, yes, we're going to clearly focus on retaining as much volume, but what's also important is what we want to do is also make sure that we are retaining the profitabilities, the profits, the focus is not volume. I just want to get volume because the economics on that volume both inside and outside is different. I also have to compare that to what I can do in my existing businesses, and my new businesses, and where I am going to allocate those dollars. So, you got to look at this in a very holistic way and the focus really needs to be on what we're doing to grow our franchise overall.

KEVIN ST. PIERRE: Great, Ken. Thank you very much.

KEN CHENAULT: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5Y4R-P5Y1-JBJN-M4GC-00000-00"American Express seeks to be relevant in the digital age"2020-02-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexis"American Express seeks to be relevant in the digital age"


The payment company has designed a strategy based on three pillars: the development of its own technology, the commercial alliances and the entry into innovative start-ups.
The payment industry is tacking a challenge marked by the confluence of digitization and regulation, with PSD2 at the forefront. American Express is no stranger to the "challenge of staying active and relevant in the digital age," explains Juan Orti, CEO of the US multinational in Spain, a country that has gained weight in the company following the decision to move its legal headquarters for continental Europe from the UK to Spain to Brexit.


The historic financial firm has designed a strategy based on three pillars: technology development, partnerships and the purchase or taking of innovative start-up stakes. An approach that pursues it, among other objectives, "to be essential in the digital life" of its customers, highlights the executive.

More than half of customers who access online accounts do so via mobile

"Technology is necessary because consumer habits are becoming more digital." For example, Orti indicates that more than half of the users who access American Express online accounts do so on mobile. However, the executive nuances that "technology is a tool for a purpose, which is to provide the best experience and value beyond the transaction".
Orti explains that the sum of digitization and regulation translates into a "commitization of the means of payment". The role of American Express, however, goes beyond ensuring safe and easy payment. "This is necessary but not enough for our business model, which rests on giving additional value to the stakeholders in the transaction through assets such as rewards, relevant marketing, access to experiences, etc., actions whose scope is even greater thanks to technology," he says.
For example, artificial intelligence allows American Express to recommend via mobile to a cardholder a restaurant according to their tastes when visiting a city, making it easier for them to book; or suggest when geolocating the customer at an airport the best lounge based on their loyalty programs. "Technology doesn't just make transactions easier and safer. The use of big data or artificial intelligence allows us to bring that customer experience that sets us apart from other players," he says.
End of card?
Orti recognizes that we are witnessing a change in consumers' payment habits. Are we at the end of cash and plastic cards? "It's bold to write down what's going to happen. Metallicis is still widely used in Spain, rather than in other assimilable neighbouring countries, but everything points to it disappearing, the question is when. And the same with plastic. What matters to us is not the form factor but to give value, regardless of the medium," he says.

The drag on technology and alliances has caused mobile payment to accelerate

One of the formulas American Express is employing to squeeze the possibilities of the digital age is the development of its own technology. For example, the company has a mobile app where it has incorporated "differential factors like payment with points", says Orti.
Another novelty is the possibility for the user to create a list of trusted online stores that prevents American Express from having to send authentication notifications on each purchase, without compromising security.
Apple and Google
The company also does nothas turned its back on business alliances, an area in which agreements with Apple Pay and Android Pay (Google) stand out. "More than half of our customers have their American Express cards in these wallets. These agreements provide us with differential technology in this payment chain link," he says. "The drag effect of these tech companies, the safe and very simple use experience, and the partnerships they have reached with companies like ours have caused mobile payment to accelerate," the executive stresses.
The company has also announced an extension of its agreement with PayPal in the United States, which for years allowed users to associate this payment system with their American Express cards. It now also offers options such as instantly splitting charges across multiple people (Transaction P2P), splitting and deferring the charge, or paying with points, for example.

"We are looking for companies with technology and models with a disruptor and accelerator element"

The third leg of the digital strategy goes through innovative start-up buying and taking part through Amex Ventures,the venture capital arm that created the company in 2011 with $100 million of funds, and which accumulates 64 investments according to Crunchbase. "We're looking for companies that have technology and business models with that disruptive and accelerator element that allows American Express to move forward and complete its proposal. The criterion is that your input is relevant, scalable and complementary."
Investments
The company has invested in technologies that strengthen its capabilities as well as leisure, gastronomy and travel apps. For example, it acquired Accertify,with state-of-the-art technology for the prevention of fraud in cyber-purchases. The company has an operational hub in American Express offices in Madrid, from where it serves international online establishments.
He is also in the stock of BioCatch,a company that uses biometrics to prevent cyberattacks, analyzing the actions of hackers to identify malicious behaviors and stop them in real time.
In April, Amex Ventures acquired LoungeBuddy,a digital platform that allows travelers to discover, book and access airport lounges around the world. This summer, it was made with the Resy restaurant booking platform.
"We are aware that competition is not just traditional players"
The media industry has seen new players break into new players, both 'fintech' and big tech like Apple or Google,not to mention the strength of companies like Alipay (Alibaba) or Tencent (owner of WeChat) in China. "Payment methods are not the most profitable industry. Why are you coming in? Fundamentally, by linking users, which provides data, a very valuable element of attraction. We are aware that competition is not just traditional players and that the PSD2 regulation requires you to cooperate," says Juan Orti. In this sense, the company looks at new categories such as the payment initiators, where it moves token. "In England we have launched a product that allows the consumer to pay in online stores through their bank account. It is a very important strategic movement because to some extent we compete with ourselves but it allows us to reach customers who do not want additional value, they only seek immediacy and security".

Also, Flushing Financial and Empire Bancorp push the date for their expected deal completion, a look at trading revenue at the world's leading investment banks, and legislation that could restrain Big Tech.

Top stories

American Express to acquire digital lender Kabbage

American Express Co. has agreed to acquire substantially all of Kabbage Inc. in a deal that will expand the credit card company's digital cash flow management offerings for small businesses.

Flushing Financial, Empire Bancorp move expected merger close

New York in-state peers Flushing Financial Corp. and Empire Bancorp Inc. agreed to extend the expected completion of their pending merger to the fourth quarter from the previously anticipated second-quarter close.

5 de novo banks withdraw applications from FDIC in July

Five de novo banks withdrew their applications from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in July, according to the regulator's actions report.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan top gainers in strong Q2 i-bank trading

PE compliance functions in focus as SEC uncovers conflicts of interest

Push to delist Chinese companies carries risk to US exchanges, influence

More highlights

* Canadian exchange operator TMX Group Ltd. appointed John McKenzie CEO, effective immediately.

* Morgan Stanley analyst resumed coverage of First Horizon National Corp., writing that the bank faces hurdles following the closing of its merger with IBERIABANK.

* Nashville, Tenn.-based FB Financial Corp. completed the previously announced merger with Franklin, Tenn.-based Franklin Financial Network Inc., effective Aug. 15.

Chart of the day

M3F Inc. initiated five new bank stock positions worth a combined $9.1 million during the second quarter, according to the firm's most recent Form 13F filing. The investment manager's largest exit was a $6.3 million investment in Salt Lake City-based Zions Bancorp. NA, which was its largest new entry in the first quarter. M3F exited eight positions worth a combined $16.8 million as of March 31.
