urn:contentItem:3XT1-NDD0-009B-G3JH-00000-00American Home Products and Warner-Lambert Confirm Merger Talks; Nasdaq Closes Above 3,0001999-11-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisCNN MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR 18:30 pm ETBusinessSHOW99110300V19American Home Products and Warner-Lambert Confirm Merger Talks; Nasdaq Closes Above 3,000Willow Bay, Stuart Varney, Rhonda Schaffler, Ceci Rodgers, Fred Katayama, Bruce Francis, Peter Viles, Bob Beard, Steve Young, Susan Lisovicz

American Home Products and Warner-Lambert today confirmed that they are in talks to join forces in what investors expect will be a merger of equals with power shared 50/50. If the two drug giants reach an agreement, it could unleash a new wave of industry deal- making. The estimated value of the deal is $65 billion, which would eclipse all other drug mergers to date. Prospects for the biggest drug merger ever and continued buying in high-tech issues combined to send stocks higher today. The Dow closed up 27 points at 10,609. The Nasdaq composite broke 3,000, and this time stayed there, closing up 46 points to 3,028.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

WILLOW BAY, CNN ANCHOR: Tonight, a possible drug combination with powerful side effects: American Home Products and Warner-Lambert in talks to merge.

STUART VARNEY, CNN ANCHOR: Four sessions, four records set as the tech high fliers help the Nasdaq finally close above 3,000.

BAY: If you think the stock market's on fire, try the housing market. We'll look at the hottest regions and ask: Can it last?

VARNEY: And from the frat house vision of Wall Street in "Liar's Poker" to the freewheeling entrepreneurs of Silicon Valley, author Michael Lewis on his "New New Thing."

ANNOUNCER: This is the MONEYLINE NEWS HOUR. Reporting tonight from New York, Willow Bay and Stuart Varney.

VARNEY: Good evening, everyone, and welcome to MONEYLINE. It was the talk of Wall Street and the entire drug industry.

BAY: The prospect of one of the biggest deals ever. American Home Products and Warner-Lambert today confirmed that they're in talks to join forces in what investors expect will be a merger of equals with power shared 50/50. If the two drug giants reach an agreement, it could unleash a new wave of industry deal-making. The estimated value of the deal is $65 billion, which would eclipse all other drug mergers to date. It is expected to be announced tomorrow.

VARNEY: Now, a merger would bring together blockbuster prescription drugs and over-the-counter staples. AHP produces the most prescribed drug in America: the estrogen replacer Premarin as well as Advil and Anacin. Warner-Lambert makes the bestselling cholesterol fighter, Lipitor, along with Listerine, Certs and other pharmacy mainstays.

BAY: If AHP does complete a deal with Warner-Lambert, it will come after two aborted merger attempts with other drug giants. Early last year, SmithKline Beecham broke off talks with AHP on management differences over who would run the company. Months later, AHP and Monsanto called off their $34 billion merger plans: the biggest deal ever to fall apart.

VARNEY: Now, Wall Street's reaction to news of a possible merger was nothing short of electric. Both American Home Products and Warner-Lambert jumped more than 5 1/2 points and both were among the most active stocks on the "Big Board."

The rally must have been a relief to AHP's long-suffering shareholders. The stock fell off a cliff back in April as the legal battle heated up over Fen-Phen. And even with recent gains, AHP is still off 20 percent from its high.

Meanwhile, Warner-Lambert shares were on fire even before word of merger talks. The stock is up more than 20 points this past month alone, and today, it hit a new 52-week high.

BAY: That merger news lifted the mood of the overall market. But the real fireworks were on the Nasdaq, which crossed the 3,000 level and stayed there for the first time today. The index jumped 46 points to end at 3,028, its fourth-straight record close.

Rhonda Schaffler has more on that milestone and those hot drug stocks in today's "Street Sweep."

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RHONDA SCHAFFLER, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Prospects for the biggest drug merger ever and continued buying in high-tech issues combined to send stocks higher today.

Drug stocks soared on word that American Home Products and Warner--Lambert might merge. Both Merck and Johnson & Johnson helped lead the Dow higher. The Dow closed up 27 points at 10,609. And the Nasdaq composite again hit 3,000, and this time stayed there, closing up 46 points to 3,028.

The index has more than doubled from last October, and some say 3,000 is just the beginning.

STUART FREEMAN, A.G. EDWARDS: You're starting to see slower economic news on a variety of fronts, and bonds are finally responding to that, and equities are responding to the bonds. And I think, you know, that 3,000 -- that 3,000 mark is something we're going to move above and well over as we move in to next year.

SCHAFFLER: The day's big tech winners included on the big boardAOL, up more than five after announcing it took a stake in Blockbuster; Oracle, which surged after (UNINTELLIGIBLE). And chip- related stocks were higher after a trade group reported late yesterday of a surge in orders.

Some are wondering whether a tech-led rally is a good thing.

RICHARD MCCABE, MERRILL LYNCH: My concern is that either some new leadership comes along, some new driving force, or these extended, somewhat maybe tired technologies may need a break. And that might be that last pullback we get sometime in the winter.

SCHAFFLER: While there are more stocks participating in the market's advance, financial stocks again failed to join in. (END VIDEOTAPE)

SCHAFFLER: One group of lagging stocks didn't dampen sentiment here, though. Traders were encouraged by the broad-based buying we've seen lately. Even small-cap stocks are back in favor -- Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Rhonda. Rhonda Schaffler from the New York Stock Exchange.

VARNEY: There is no doubt this is the year for the Nasdaq composite. It's by far the best-performing major index.

Since breaking the 2,000 barrier 15 months ago, the Nasdaq has soared 49 percent. That's almost four times the gain of the S&P 500 during the same period and the Dow industrials as well. The only other time the Nasdaq composite has outperformed the Dow and S&P by this much was in 1991 when the economy was recovering from a recession.

Keep in mind, the Nasdaq has only been around since 1971.

BAY: The stock market's incredible bull run has helped drive what is shaping up to be the economy's best peacetime expansion ever. But today, a report showed that supertanker USA may finally be slowing down to the point where the Federal Reserve may be able to stop raising interest rates.

From Chicago, here's Ceci Rodgers.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CECI RODGERS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Signs the economy might be cooling off a bit are raising hopes that the sharp rise in interest rates this year may be largely over. A recent slowdown in housing and construction showed up in the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey, a region-by region snapshot of economic conditions.

JOHN STILES, IDEA: I think "The Beige Book" this afternoon, which is the report that will go to the FOMC meeting in the middle of November, said it pretty well. The economy is still experiencing strong growth, but some slowing is seen.

RODGERS: Still, the survey noted a rebound in manufacturing and tight labor markets that are boosting wages. So far, those wage costs are not being passed along to consumers thanks to rising productivity.

But some economists are worried .

PAUL KASRIEL, NORTHERN TRUST CO.: District after district reported tight labor markets, difficulty in finding staff. Turnover is -- is moving up in a very rate, and that's got to hurt productivity.

RODGERS: The bond market has factored in about a 50 percent chance of a third hike in short-term interest rates when the Fed meets later this month. MICHELLE GIRARD, PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES: As long as the Fed is being viewed as pre-emptive, I also don't think it has to mean dramatically higher bond yields, because again this idea that the Fed is doing the right thing to keep inflation low will help to keep long- term interest rates in check.

RODGERS: The next big inflation test comes Friday with October's employment report. It's the last official look at payrolls and wages before the Greenspan Fed sits down to set interest rate policy in less than two weeks.

Ceci Rodgers, CNN Financial News, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: The bond market did not show much reaction to today's economic news: the 30-year Treasury edged up 2/32 of a point in price. The yield tonight at 6.13 percent.

VARNEY: Tobacco stocks joined technology as the big winners today. They rallied on potentially favorable news out of that landmark trial in Florida.

The Florida Supreme Court is asking plaintiffs to respond to a petition by cigarette makers. It asks the court to prevent punitive damages, which could cost the companies billions of dollars. The court did not say it would formally review the petition, but investors viewed it as a step in the right direction.

Shares of Philip Morris, RJ Reynolds, Loews, UST, BAT, all moving sharply higher on the day's trading. We will have more on this story later on MONEYLINE.

BAY: Much more ahead, and for a preview of some of it, we turn now to some of MONEYLINE's other reporters, beginning with Fred Katayama -- Fred.

FRED KATAYAMA, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Willow. Much more on the AHP/Warner-Lambert merger talks. If it happens, it would combine two of the bestselling drugs in America under one roof. But is bigger really better?

BRUCE FRANCIS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: I'm Bruce Francis. It calls itself the market for the next century, but it crossed another millennium mark today. And I'll tell you why most Nasdaq stocks, though, had little to celebrate.

PETER VILES, CNN CORRESPONDENT: And I'm Peter Viles. You wouldn't know it from the way the stock market dominates the news, but more Americans are making money in real estate than on Wall Street. Ahead, the hidden wealth effect of the housing market -- Willow.

BAY: Thanks, Peter. Much more still ahead on MONEYLINE. In the wake of the EgyptAir crash, Boeing's chief executive comes out fighting for the 767. But do the safety stats make his case?

VARNEY: And Qualcomm dials up a stock surge. But are tougher times about to come calling?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: A major legal offensive by the government today against some leading utilities in the East and Midwest. The Clinton administration filed suits alleging the companies caused massive air pollution.

Bob Beard has our report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BOB BEARD, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Seven electric utilities holding companies were hit with federal lawsuits, accusing them of spewing millions of tons of harmful pollutants into the air from older coal-burning power plants.

CAROL BROWNER, EPA ADMINISTRATOR: We will not allow these companies to pollute our air, our water. We will not allow them to disregard the requirements of the Clean Air Act.

BEARD: The lawsuits come after a two-year EPA investigation. The companies sued American Electric Power, Cinergy, FirstEnergy, Illinois Power, Southern Indiana Gas & Electric, Southern Company and Tampa Electric. The EPA says they spent hundreds of millions of dollars putting new burners and furnaces on 32 old power plants, but not anti-pollution equipment, ignoring a 1970 law requiring them to install such equipment when making upgrades.

BROWNER: They made these modifications to stay in business longer, because it was profitable. They could have made a modest investment in the public's health. They could have easily put these pollution control technologies on.

BEARD: In response, one lawyer who represents the industry trade group contends the plants meets all clean air standards, and the EPA's lawsuit is changing the rules.

HENRY NICKLE, UTILITY AIR REGULATORY GROUP: It could have a devastating effect on the economy, because of the fact you could not undertake any project that's needed to improve efficiency, improve reliability.

BEARD: Doug Fisher, who follows the utility industry at A.G. Edwards, says the seven utilities may be forced to spend more on new equipment.

DOUG FISHER, A.G. EDWARDS: It's going to result in, over the long term, some kind of compromise, we believe, that will require that some of these plants eventually put on more pollution-control equipment.

BEARD (on camera): For now though, the utilities could face EPA fines of up to $27,000 per plant, per day.

Bob Beard, for CNN Financial News, Washington. (END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Boeing's chief executive today defended his company's safety record. It was a Boeing 767 that crashed off Nantucket Island Sunday, killing all 217 aboard EgyptAir flight 990. Phil Condit spoke to reporters in Washington, saying that people should feel safe flying a jetliner.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

PHIL CONDIT, CHAIRMAN & CEO, BOEING: If you look at 18 years, we've had a total of three crashes. One of them was a result of a hijacker. The Lauda Air crash, and now the EgyptAir crash; that's really two crashes if I take out the hijacking, two in 18 years.

There's no airplane that has a better safety record over that length of time, period.

So should there be confidence? Absolutely.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: Investigators still do not know what caused the crash. Bad weather today stalled the recovery effort and the search for the flight recorders. U.S. investigators are looking into whether a deactivated engine part played a role in the disaster. A full interview with Boeing's Bill Condit will air at 8:00 p.m. Eastern time tonight on "THE WORLD TODAY" right here on CNN.

Boeing's stock, meanwhile, fell for third straight day, closing at 43 1/4.

VARNEY: Echostar Communications tops tonight's "MONEYLINE Movers." It was up 6 1/4. PaineWebber raised its price target to $76 a share. It cited strong subscriber growth at the satellite TV company, and said ti expects continued strong performance at the strong quarter of next year.

Xilinx up 4 1/2. The chipmakers joins the S&P 500 on Friday. It will replace communications equipment company Harris. Appnet soared nearly 8 1/2. It will develop technologies for NASA to help scientists monitor and control satellites from a secured Internet site. And TMP Worldwide, up almost 10 points. It beat third-quarter estimates by a nickel. It cited strong performance at its monster.com employment Web site.

BAY: It was quite a day for Qualcomm. The stock soared after it reported a strong fourth quarter, thanks to record sales of its mobile phone products. Qualcomm beat estimates by 3 cents a shares and announced a 4-for-1 stock flit yesterday, Today, its stock rocketed more than 25 percent, adding to its incredible gains this past year.

But as Steve Young reports in today's "Leading Edge" report, some are raising the red flag.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) STEVE YOUNG, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A one-day spurt of more than $35 in Qualcomm's stock gives a good measure of the company's stratospheric projectory. Qualcomm has more than quintupled in just the last eight months.

Qualcomm owns patents on one of the dominant cellphone transmission companies, known as CDMA, and it makes chips that go into the phones.

But some question how long the boom can continue. Cellphone makers pay a royalty to Qualcomm, but they're engaged in a price war. The cheaper the cellphones, the smaller the royalty.

On top of that, Qualcomm faces new chip competition. Intel, the biggest chipmaker, just bought DSP Communications which also makes CDMA chips, and Motorola is getting into the market, too.

EDWARD SNYDER, HAMBRECHT & QUIST: If you look into 2000, I mean, you see a lot of competitive problems, I think, for Qualcomm. Any one of those, if it comes to fruition, is going to cause a maybe flattening of earnings and that will, in our opinion, tank the stock.

YOUNG: But Qualcomm chairman Irwin Jacobs says his competitors won't catch up.

IRWIN JACOBS, CHAIRMAN & CEO, QUALCOMM: We're ahead of the market now, of the other manufacturers. We intend to stay there. And so we're bringing out chips that have a significant data capability, and we will continue to make them smaller, require less power. We think we're well positioned.

YOUNG: Most analyst say, even homemakers using different technical standards will have to pay royalties to use Qualcomm's patents for their next-generation cell phones.

ALEX CENA, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: Well, one piece that a lot of investors and analysts have missed on Qualcomm is, in their minds, it's irrelevant who wins -- Nokia, Motorola, Intel, in the future, Lucent -- all of those companies are Qualcomm licensees.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

YOUNG: Analysts are also encouraged that Qualcomm intends to sell off its unprofitable unit that makes phones and stick to selling the chip technology where it dominates -- Willow.

BAY: Steve, thank you.

Steve Young reporting.

Coming up on MONEYLINE: the Nasdaq spends its first night above 3,000. Is this a surge of tech enthusiasm or the rise of a new economy?

VARNEY: Well, we'll speak live with top Morgan Stanley strategist Leah Modigliani. That interview and more after this break. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Checking some of the stocks that hit new 52-week highs today: Duetsche Telekom, Gateway, Kenneth Cole Productions, Saatchi & Saatchi and Applied Materials.

VARNEY: Now some of the day's top stories outside the world of business. A day after the man accused of killing seven at a Xerox building in Hawaii surrendered, another workplace shooting, this time in Seattle. Two are dead, two wounded, after a gunmen opened fire at a Seattle shipyard. The unidentified attacker escaped on foot and remains at large at this hour.

A guilty verdict today in the case against the Wyoming man accused of killing gay college student Matthew Shepard. Twenty-two- year-old Aaron McKinney was found guilty of felony murder and could face the death penalty. The sentencing phase begins tomorrow.

BAY: Turning back to Wall Street's big moment, the victory lap for the Nasdaq: covering 3,000 for the first time.

Our guest tonight is an up and coming strategist who has the business in her blood. Her grandfather was the 1985 Nobel laureate in economics. Leah Modigliani of Dean Witter joins us.

Welcome.

LEAH MODIGLIANI, MORGAN STANLEY DEAN WITTER: Thank you.

BAY: So of course the big news of the day was the Nasdaq. Is this climb sustainable? Is there anything that you see on the horizon standing in the Nasdaq's way?

MODIGLIANI: A lot of these stocks are priced for perfection, and so if something goes wrong, I think these stocks will feel it. These milestones have been hard to achieve. When the Dow Reached the 10,000 point, really had some struggles before it could cross it, most certainly. So I would think that we'd see a similar situation here, that some of the tech stocks will struggle around this level. They're at very high levels.

But I think that technology is what America does best, and these companies are really the world's technology companies.

BAY: Do you still think, as you did this summer, that the markets are overvalued?

MODIGLIANI: I do.

BAY: By how much?

MODIGLIANI: It's in the range of 25 percent to 30 percent at this point.

BAY: Still, even after the correction that we've just gone through? MODIGLIANI: Even after the correction. And also, interest rates have come down, which has helped. But the P/E ratios are still very high.

BAY: So is this across the board, or are certain stocks heightening that affect?

MODIGLIANI: No, certain stocks are definitely heightening that affect. The technology stocks are really very hot, still. But there are still stocks that are affordable. There are still stocks that are cheaper, and that's where we're looking to put new money to work.

BAY: Let's go through your fresh money buy list. You have stocks like AOL, Cisco, AMR, Warner-Lambert. Cisco -- still headed higher, even at 71?

MODIGLIANI: Cisco has been an amazing stock, and we still like it. It is just something that we think is going to be a winner in this new economy and in the Internet. So we're sticking with Cisco, even though it's had a great run here.

BAY: How about Warner-Lambert? They've confirmed they're in talks. Will consolidation, in this industry, improve performance?

MODIGLIANI: That's debatable. I think that the pharmaceuticals have seen some slowing in their growth recently, and I think they're turning to mergers and acquisitions as a way to keep the growth in earnings and cut costs and really, you know, improve their profits.

BAY: Real quickly on your list, Circuit City -- why?

MODIGLIANI: Circuit City -- I love Circuit City. Circuit City is really play on digital equipment. We think that they have some exciting new products, and for Christmas people are going to be buying digital cameras and DVDs and, eventually in the future, digital TVs.

BAY: Still buy what you recommend?

MODIGLIANI: We really like it.

BAY: Still buy what you recommend?

MODIGLIANI: Absolutely. I absolutely buy the stocks I recommend.

BAY: Leah Modigliani, thanks for joining us tonight on MONEYLINE.

MODIGLIANI: Thank you.

BAY: Stuart.

VARNEY: Thanks, Willow.

Still to come on MONEYLINE: the stock upset. What makes them tick? What makes them succeed? Michael Lewis, the author of "The New New Thing," takes us inside the entrepreneurial roots of two Silicon Valley success stories.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: We have already brought you one list of stocks hitting new highs today. There are so many of them, we're going to bring you another list, topped by Broadcom, then comes KLA-Tencor, Lam Research, and look at this, Oracle, another new high there, and Novellus Systems again, too.

BAY: And there's still a lot more to come on MONEYLINE tonight. A huge cheer on Wall Street for what could be the drug industry's biggest merger ever. We've got the details.

VARNEY: And the second time is a charm, for Nasdaq 3000 that is. Today it climbed there, and it stayed there.

BAY: And the wealth affect -- it doesn't just come from the stock market anymore. We'll go inside the boom in home prices.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's headlines, a crowning achievement for the index of the year, Nasdaq 3,000. Tonight, a look at the road to 3K and the enormous wealth it's created.

From one boom to another, more Americans are making money in real estate than on Wall Street, and Alan Greenspan is paying attention.

And the entrepreneurs of Silicon Valley: What kind of people are they and how do they operate? There's a new book on that, and we'll talk to the author. He's the man who wrote "Liar's Poker": Michael Lewis.

BAY: First, our top story: the prospect of another blockbuster merger in the drug business. American Home Products and Warner- Lambert are talking about a deal that could be worth as much as $65 billion. It would be one of the biggest corporate tie-ups ever, certainly the largest of its kind.

American Home Products has been looking for a partner, but talks fell through with Monsanto and SmithKline Beecham. Investors are betting the third time's a charm, sending AHP stock up more than 5 1/2. Warner-Lambert jumped by the same amount.

Fred Katayama has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA (voice-over): A union between the maker of Advil: American Home Products, and its rival, Warner-Lambert, would produce the biggest drug merger in history, more than double that of the biggest to date.

BOB KIRBY, EDWARD JONES: In this industry, bigger is better, given the pricetag of developing a new drug to the tune of $500 million. In order to take advantage of these projects as they come along, you really need to have the right size to be able to do that.

KATAYAMA: Analysts say the two companies complement each other. American Home is strong in women's health products, especially with its Estrogen tablet, Premarin. Warner-Lambert's expertise lies in diabetes and cholesterol drugs like Lipitor.

A merger would also create a leader in consumer products, marrying AHP's Anacin pain reliever and Robitussin cough syrup with Warner-Lambert's Schick razors.

Together, the two would create a company with nearly $24 billion in revenue and prescription drug sales of almost $14 billion: scale that could give rivals migraines. It could control more than 5 percent of the global prescription drug market. Many analysts predict it will pass muster with antitrust regulators, because there's little overlap of product lines.

HERMAN SAFTLAS, STANDARD AND POOR'S: None of these companies account for a significant part of the market. They only account for, you know, 1 or 2 percent of any given class.

No. 2, if there is a problem, it usually involves a divestiture of one or two minor products.

KATAYAMA: The companies could also trim overlapping sales and marketing forces, which one analyst estimates could produce savings of more than a billion dollars.

Drug stocks rose as investors bet that merger fever would spread to others.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

KATAYAMA: AHP's stock could use an antidepressant. A series of legal problems had weighed on the stock. American Home recently struck a multibillion dollar settlement over its diet drugs, known as Fen-Phen: a move analysts say makes it a more attractive merger candidate and removes some of the uncertainty hanging over its stock.

BAY: Fred, do you expect we'll hear an announcement tomorrow?

KATAYAMA: That's the rumor mill on Wall Street. The companies won't comment.

BAY: Thanks, Fred. Fred Katayama reporting.

VARNEY: Now, the run-up in drug stocks gave the Dow its first winning session of the week. The blue chip index up 27, to finish at 10,609. The volume, 914 million shares.

But the true standout today was the Nasdaq composite. That tech- heavy index blew past the 3,000 level and it stayed there for the first time ever. It was up 46 points to close at 3,028.

Now, that is a fourth-straight record and the Nasdaq's first close above 3,000: a milestone not all market watchers are celebrating.

Bruce Francis reports.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS (voice-over): As the Nasdaq closes above 3,000 for the first time, there's no champagne on ice at Muriel Siebert & Company. And the first lady of Wall Street is not terribly impressed.

MURIEL SIEBERT, CEO, MURIEL SIEBERT & CO.: I think this milestone is a great round number. But it does not mean that the whole market has hit -- that every stock has hit a new high. It's specific stocks. They're very heavily weighted in the indexes and the averages. But it's a great time because it shows that people are willing to put money into the stocks again.

FRANCIS: The Nasdaq composite is dominated by stocks with huge market values. So as the biggest stocks get bigger, so does the composite.

Today, for example, the top five of the most active stocks accounted for about a third of the index and half of today's point gain. Big gains in Nasdaq stalwarts, like Sun Microsystems and Cisco, helped propel the composite. And gains from some of the Nasdaq's other large-cap stocks have boosted the index during the 16-month ride from 2,000 to 3,000.

But some big stocks have dwindled in value during the same period. And so far this year, most Nasdaq stocks are actually down.

So while another millennium milestone may sound impressive for a system that calls itself the stock market for the next century, analysts who watch key numbers for a living aren't celebrating.

GREG NIE, FIRST UNION SECURITIES: 3,000 is not a particularly important number technically in our work. If you look at it from the standpoint of whether the market is extended or not, the Nasdaq composite chart moving averages, trend lines and so forth, it's not shaping up as a key number.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

FRANCIS: Technical analysts would like to see rallies like today's to be broader, but some say that small cap stocks can't take off until this tidal wave of IPOs slows down -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Well, Bruce, does Wall Street have a collective opinion about where the Nasdaq goes from here?

FRANCIS: It's hard to say. There's great demand out there, Stuart. The latest thing, though, a tamer inflation outlook is great for these stocks, since they have so many of their earnings way out in the future and inflation eats into those like crazy. That's much better for these stocks.

VARNEY: Yes, indeed. Bruce Francis reporting. Thank you, Bruce.

BAY: A closer look behind today's modest rally shows it was pretty broad-based. Gainers on the big board ran ahead of losers by a 16-to-13 margin. The number of new 52-week highs, 55 versus the number of new lows, 95.

Among today's winners: General Electric, up nearly 2 1/2, its second day of gains. Tyco International rose 1 1/2, again one of the most active stocks on the big board. Texas Instruments added 2 3/4, and Oxford Health Care rallied 1 5/8 after reporting much-better-than- expected earnings late yesterday.

In the bond market, an early rally fizzled, even after several inflation-friendly economic reports. The 30-year Treasury up 2/32; the yield at 6.13 percent.

VARNEY: The stock market's great bull run of the 1990s has had economists watching the so-called "wealth effect": the idea that Americans are more inclined to spend money if stocks are doing well. But this week, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan offered his thoughts on the subject, pointing out the many for many Americans the bigger wealth effect is in the one they live in.

Peter Viles takes a special MONEYLINE look at the benefits of the housing boom.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

VILES (voice-over): The bull market of the '90s, one of the great wealth machines of all time, but many Americans are getting rich a lot closer to home.

Housing prices have been climbing steadily for years, and not just in wealthy suburbs. The hottest housing markets over the past four years: Detroit, where median prices are up 46 percent, New Orleans, San Francisco, Houston, and yes, Saginaw, Michigan.

(on camera): A few years ago, you could find a house in this Long Island neighborhood for $400,000. But since then, prices have spiked: 600,000 is not unusual. And if you see a house you like, you'd better be ready to put a bid down on it the same day.

EMMA MCMAHON, COLDWELL BANDER SAMMIS: From January to June it was absolute bedlam. But still, we're putting a house on the market in Flower Hill priced at 649, coming on the market Friday. I don't think it'll go through the weekend. We still have more buyers than there are homes.

VILES (voice-over): The economic impact is significant. Alan Greenspan argues, and many economists agree, money gained from selling a house is more likely to be spent than money gained in the stock market. That's partly because stock market gains are concentrated among the wealthy and partly because people believe housing prices are less likely to fall.

DELOS SMITH, THE CONFERENCE BOARD: The family probably thinks that 25,000 from the housing, yes, we've made it. You know, that's the -- that really becomes so important to them. But on the equities, he'll say, well, Microsoft can go up and down and I can lose it. The 25,000, it's in his pocket. He got it.

VILES: And bear in mind, even after the incredible bull market we've seen, real estate is a more common investment than stocks: 67 percent of American families own houses, only 48 percent own stocks.

Peter Viles, CNN Financial News, Manhasset, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAY: Coming up, some of the day's biggest stock movers. Plus, score one for the tobacco industry.

VARNEY: The Florida Supreme Court makes a surprising decision in the landmark class-action case and lights a fire under tobacco stocks. The details when MONEYLINE returns.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Commerce One tops tonight's other movers. It soared nearly 47. The e-commerce service firm will help General Motors create an Internet marketplace that will link GM's suppliers and dealers. Real Networks up 10 1/8 on speculation Yahoo! could make a takeover bid. Yahoo! would not comment on the rumors, and one analyst said the CFO of Real Networks was unaware of the speculation.

Apple Computer up 1 1/4. Bear Stearns raised its price target based on confidence in its near-term outlook.

And Qualcomm soared nearly 35 3/4. Two analysts raised their price target after Qualcomm reporter better-than-expected earnings late yesterday. Qualcomm also announced a four for one stock split. Its shares up more than 900 percent for the year.

VARNEY: A potential break in a Florida class-action case that threatens to overwhelm the tobacco industry. And as Susan Lisovicz reports, the surprising news gave a big boost to tobacco shares.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): In July, a Florida jury found cigarette makers liable for smoking-related illnesses in potentially hundreds of thousands of smokers. Now, a four-sentence order from the state's highest court has the potential to limit the damages the tobacco industry might have to pay out.

Cigarette makers appealed to the Florida state supreme court just last Friday on the potentially devastating issue of whether punitive damages could be awarded in a lump sum to the entire class of smokers.

JACK COFFEE, COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY LAW SCHOOL: It indicates that the Florida Supreme Court is taking very seriously the defendants' objections to any attempt to assess punitive damages at this second phase of the trial. And punitive damages is where the bottom line is for the industry, because they could be potentially liable for as much as $300 billion.

LISOVICZ: Wall Street had not expected the state's highest court to take jurisdiction in a case that is still being argued before the lower courts. Tobacco stocks soared on the news, led by industry leader Philip Morris, though the Dow component is still down nearly 50 percent for the year.

Some analysts say the Florida Supreme Court's involvement at this early stage may be a turning point.

MARTIN FELDMAN, SALOMONSMITH BARNEY: It could be the beginning of the start of real difficulties for the plaintiffs' case, and of course, that's pretty good news for the tobacco industry. But it's my speculation that eventually punitive damages will not be allowed to be assessed on a class-wide basis in this case.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LISOVICZ: The Florida Supreme Court has ordered the plaintiffs' lawyers to respond by November 15th. Wall Street is encouraged not only by the court's rapid response to the tobacco industry's appeal, but the speed in which it's trying to resolve the issue -- Stuart.

VARNEY: Susan Lisovicz reporting. Thank you, Susan.

BAY: 58 days until Y2K and news tonight that software companies are beginning to staff up. In anticipation of heavy call volume on help lines, Microsoft will have about 3,000 people on hand for the changeover. And Computer Associates is contemplating spending $6 million for extra staffing to make sure clients can find human beings at the end of the Y2K help line.

VARNEY: That would be nice.

BAY: Coming up next on MONEYLINE, a new book on how to make a billion dollars '90s style: turning "The New New Thing" into a ".com" sensation.

VARNEY: We'll hear from author Michael Lewis on his dispatch from inside the world of the digital elite. Stay with us please.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: In tonight's MONEYLINE "Focus": "The New New Thing" from author Michael Lewis. He wrote the 1980s bestseller "Liar's Poker," a scathing insider account of the brash bond traders at Salomon.

Now, he's out with "The New New Thing," a 1990s account of maverick entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley.

I began by asking Mr. Lewis how the digital elite compares with the Wall Street stars of the '80s.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MICHAEL LEWIS, AUTHOR, "THE NEW NEW THING": One is much bigger and more powerful that the other, I think. The Silicon Valley people are just, you know -- they make the Wall Street people look like they're playing in a low-stakes poker table.

VARNEY (on camera): Is it just that much money on the table?

LEWIS: Oh, it's that much bigger. Yes, it's that much bigger.

They're also, you know -- historically, Wall Street people have sat on top of the food chain. You know, there's nothing new about Wall Street people running the economy.

These guys who are now sitting on top of the food chain, they've never been there before, you know. It's like the New Orleans Saints having a winning season, a group of people who you didn't really expect to do well doing as well as they are.

VARNEY: Would you make the value judgment that they deserve to be sitting where they're sitting?

LEWIS: I think they're more deserving of it than the Wall Street people were. I think there's a question of whether anybody deserves to have that kind of economic power. But they're unquestionably producing wealth, you know, that the society has come to a consensus that wealth is change, that technological change is really the source of wealth. And that's what these people specialize in: foisting change upon other people.

VARNEY: Jim Clark, founder of Silicon Graphics, founder of Netscape, the visionary behind Healtheon -- now, you write extensively about him and you say that he doesn't go to the office, he doesn't take meetings, he doesn't execute. The man doesn't manage. Is he typical of the Silicon Valley elite? A totally different lifestyle.

LEWIS: He's typical of a certain type of Silicon Valley person, and that's the person who starts things. And that person is sort of the catalyst for the whole place. He's the prime mover. He's the one who stands up and says behold the new new thing.

VARNEY: But he doesn't implement?

LEWIS: But he doesn't implement, that's right.

VARNEY: And he wouldn't be any good at implementing.

LEWIS: And he wouldn't be any good at it. He's a -- a -- you know, I refer to him as a disorganization man, that what he really does is thrive on chaos.

VARNEY: Now, there's a great deal of wealth that's being created here. And currently, it's on paper. It's the new wealth of the new economy. Do you ever feel that it's perhaps a house of cards that could come crashing down? Any chance of that?

LEWIS: Oh, sure. But you know, this is one of those situations where perceptions create their own reality, that I think people believe so strongly that this is all working out that it will work out.

It's very funny. If you throw enough capital and brains at problems, the problems tend to get solved. And that's what's going on: massive amounts of capital, and you know, the best brains in the society are working on changing the society, laying a whole new infrastructure, a whole new distribution system.

VARNEY: Well, do you see any downside to all this wealth creation?

LEWIS: Well, I think the downside is -- I mean, it creates a wealthier society, but it creates a lot of disruption in the society. And the question is -- how much change can a society withstand, I think is the great question I ask?

Industries have been thrown in turmoil. You know, people are being asked to adapt to things in ways they haven't had to before, and that's, you know -- how much ruthlessness and shiftlessness can a society take?

Now, Silicon Valley people, they can take a lot of it. They're very good at it. But people outside of Silicon Valley have problems with it.

VARNEY: The elite of the '80s was one type type. The elite in Silicon Valley of the '90s was another type, a different type. Would you care to specify on what the elite of the next decade will be, where it will be located, and how it will makes its money?

LEWIS: I don't think the Silicon Valley thing has legs. I don't think it's going to be over anytime soon. I think that we're seeing the beginning of something that is going to last for awhile.

VARNEY: Is it uniquely American?

LEWIS: It's uniquely American in a lot of ways. It's uniquely American in that it depends on the capacity for social change that other societies don't have. No societies could have thrown the capital at this problem, that, you know, nobody can walk into a venture capitalist on Sam Hill Road in Silicon Valley and get $3 million just on the strength of an idea. That doesn't happen anywhere else.

VARNEY: That's very true. There you have it. A true believer in the Internet. "The New New Thing" from Michael Lewis.

BAY: Stay with us. We'll be back right after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

VARNEY: A new market may be opening up for Prozac. An FDA panel today approved the use of the top selling antidepressant to treat a severe form of premenstrual syndrome. The FDA OK may be good news for Eli Lily, which has seen growth in Prozac sales slow. Lily's stock up 3 points, but it is still down more than 25 percent from its 52-week high. BAY: A boost for Blockbuster, after the video retailer struck a deal with America Online. AOL will invest $30 million in Blockbuster's online business. Under the three-year deal, Blockbuster will become the premier home video provider on AOL's Entertainment Channel. Earlier on CNN, AOL's president said deals like this help it stand out from other Internet service providers.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERT PITTMAN, PRESIDENT & COO, AMERICA ONLINE: I think at the end of the day, what we've wound up being is a service which is unique, very valuable to members. We invest a lot of our money making AOL different than all the other services. We do things you can't get anywhere else, and we think at the end of the day, our members are looking for that high quality, high-priced service.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAY: Shares of AOL ended up 6-3/8. Blockbuster, a publicly traded unit of Viacom, up 1 3/8, though still below its IPO price of $15 a share.

VARNEY: Up next: Well, we've already told you about "The New New Thing." Now we're going to tell you about the new new rich.

BAY: And "Ahead of the Curve," some of what you need to know tonight, before the markets open tomorrow. You are watching MONEYLINE.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAY: Health care stocks have staged an impressive recovery this week. Tomorrow we'll find out how some of those companies fared in the third quarter, when Foundation Health and Humana report earnings. Also look for results from Starwood Hotels and Royal Dutch Petroleum. And keep an eye on shares of Scient. The stock jumped $8 in after- hours trading, after the company announced a two-for-one stock split. And the woman who has been known to move markets, Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman Sachs, speaks at the annual meeting of the Securities Industry Association.

VARNEY: And now a final note on one of our top stories: Nasdaq 3,000. The road from 2K to 3K has certainly made some of the world's richest men richer, ballooning the billionaire status of the likes of Bill Gates and Michael Dell, But the ".com" stock craze over the past 15 months has created a new social class: the new new rich. Pierre Omidyar, eBay's founder and chairman, was making $121,000 before the online auctioneer went public last year. Tonight, he's worth -- get this -- $4.7 billion, on paper that is. Jay Walker, the co-founder of Priceline.com, made $250,000 last year. Now he's worth $3.5 billion. And here's a pay raise worth repeating: Gary Winnick earned nothing from his work with Global Crossing last year, tonight, his stake is valued at $3.4 billion.

BAY: And this important note before we close: We're pleased to be able to announce that Shelby Coffey will become the new president of CNN Financial News and CNNfn. In making the official announcement today, CNN news group chairman Tom Johnson said, "We're fortunate to be joined by one of the finest and most accomplished journalists in the nation today." Coffey comes to us from ABC News, where he served as executive vice president. Prior to that, he was executive editor of "The Los Angeles Times." And we welcome him.

VARNEY: Indeed.

BAY: That is MONEYLINE for this Wednesday. I'm Willow Bay.

VARNEY: And I'm Stuart Varney. Thanks for joining us. Good- night from New York.

"CROSSFIRE" is next.

urn:contentItem:53RX-JXD1-JBF5-T118-00000-00American Innovators Lose Big in Newly Passed Patent Bill2011-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisAmerican Innovators Lose Big in Newly Passed Patent Bill

Politics, Patents, startups

Robert Nelsen wrote:

American innovation lost big again as the U.S. Senate passed "patent reform" and caved to big business lobbyists at the expense of true innovators in small companies and universities. Bottom line: America has dominated innovation in the world for 100 years based on our patent system and protection of risk-takers. Innovation is the one thing we still dominate in the world economy. It is our job engine. The first rule of governing should apply here: If it aint broke don't "fix" it.

The sponsors, Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont and Representative Lamar Smith of Texas, worked extremely hard and were well-meaning, but the big lobbyists hijacked the process. The bill was conceived to solve the problem of truly frivolous lawsuits in the technology and banking industries. That problem was solved in five minutes, and then the big companies got ahold of the Bill and added all their bells and whistles and it passed based on sheer inertia. Few in Congress like this law, but they went along because big companies have more power than true innovators. Many will cheer it just to suck up to their representatives. Not me. Few, like Senator Maria Cantwell of Washington state, had the courage to call the bill what it is and that it "tramples the rights of small inventors."

We gave some real competitive advantage to Europe and China with our "first-to-file" from first to invent. Now big companies and foreign firms with fleets of patent lawyers can "scoop" university professors and independent inventors by filing first. Our national investment in research and development has been devalued.

A lot of the reform was driven by the fat and happy tech companies like Intel, Cisco, Google and large New York banks. I call them the "infringers lobby" because their overt goal is to use their market power to steal other's ideas without paying. That is what this bill does with its business methods section and also the new "post grant review" provisions.

These poor companies, most with market caps over $100 billion, whine loudly about how they are being harassed by the little guy. Never a larger load of horse manure have I heard in my 25 years of starting companies. They have forgotten their roots as venture capital-funded companies who relied on patents to get their funding in the first place. Now that they are less innovative, bloated bureaucracies, they want to repress the innovations of the little guy.

These technology companies and big pharmaceutical companies and others will use the new post-grant review clause to slow the patent process down, and to bleed small companies dry. It happens now, and will be much worse in the future, by big companies filing objections to the true innovations over and over, drying up small inventors' ability to raise capital.

We have inadvertently put another nail in the coffin of American competitiveness. Our future, and the only way we can compete with China, is our unique ability to invent. It is the core American ideal. We can find our way out of any problem, and the little guy, be he Henry Ford, Thomas Edison, Alexander Graham Bell, Steve Jobs, Jonas Salk, or Gordon Moore, can dream big and invent new industries. All protected in their infancy by a strong patent system.

Not a single job will be created by this bill. Just happy smiles from big oil, big tech, and big pharma, lawyers and lobbyists, and with downright glee in China and the EU.

The most alarming fact is this law is just part of an even larger assault on innovation in the USA. Everywhere you turn, there is less capital available, higher taxes proposed on small business investors, more regulations on IPO companies and investors, an FDA gone wild, and crazy immigration and border policies that drive the best and brightest from our shores. The talk in Washington seems to be all about innovation saving us, and the policies seem to be all about killing it.

American Manganese Inc.Integrating Blockchain Technology to Source Lithium Ion Battery Supply

Technology will advance the circular economy and ethical sourcing

Vancouver, British Columbia (FSCwire) - Larry W. Reaugh, President and Chief Executive Officer of American Manganese Inc.("American Manganese" or "AMY" or the "Company"), (TSX.V:  AMY | OTC-US:  AMYZF | FSE:  2AM), is pleased to announce that the Company is working with Circulor Ltd. ("Circulor") of London, England, to pilot blockchain technology in order to create a traceable and ethically sourced circular economy for electric vehicle (EV) battery metals, such as cobalt.

American Manganese Inc.CEO, Larry Reaugh says, "AMY and Circulor will be mapping the lifecycle of an EV battery and understanding the value flow through the production process and lifecycle. As well as providing a road map for AMY to source valuable lithium ion batteries."

The blockchain technology will create traceability of EV battery metals from the mine through their first use and then as they are recycled.

Circulor Ltd. CEO, Doug Johnson-Poensgen, said "Blockchain technology has the potential to transform complex industrial supply chains both by assuring provenance and improving efficiency.  This joint project will create the first blockchain solution designed specifically for the EV circular economy."

AMY and Circulor will engage other industrial partners involved in the EV battery lifecycle, including car manufacturers, during the pilot.

As reference to the existing supply chain's ethical concerns for battery metals, click the following link to read the CNN article: 'Carmakers and big tech struggle to keep batteries free from child labor'. http://money.cnn.com /2018/05/01/technology/cobalt-congo-child-labor-car-smartphone-batteries/index.html

About Circulor Ltd.

Circulor Ltd. is a London (UK) based blockchain start-up focused on materials provenance in the Electric Vehicle supply chain.

Circulor are creating distributed applications to help supply chain participants prove provenance, improve supply chain transparency and reduce counterparty risk exposure.  The data pool that will be created in a blockchain ecosystem will eventually allow participants to unlock value well beyond what is currently possible, without compromising commercial confidentiality or violating antitrust/anti-competitive regulations.

The company has been engaging with a range of supply chain participants from car manufacturers to specialists in ethical and sustainable sourcing to prove the utility of blockchain technology and ensure that its solutions can integrate with existing supply chain management solutions.

Circulor is privately held.

American Manganese Inc. Integrating Blockchain Technology to Source Lithium Ion Battery Supply

Technology will advance the circular economy and ethical sourcing

Vancouver, British Columbia (FSCwire) - Larry W. Reaugh, President and Chief Executive Officer of American Manganese Inc. (American Manganese or AMY or the Company), (TSX.V: AMY | OTC-US: AMYZF | FSE: 2AM), is pleased to announce that the Company is working with Circulor Ltd. (Circulor) of London, England, to pilot blockchain technology in order to create a traceable and ethically sourced circular economy for electric vehicle (EV) battery metals, such as cobalt.

American Manganese Inc. CEO, Larry Reaugh says, AMY and Circulor will be mapping the lifecycle of an EV battery and understanding the value flow through the production process and lifecycle. As well as providing a road map for AMY to source valuable lithium ion batteries.

The blockchain technology will create traceability of EV battery metals from the mine through their first use and then as they are recycled.

Circulor Ltd. CEO, Doug Johnson-Poensgen, said Blockchain technology has the potential to transform complex industrial supply chains both by assuring provenance and improving efficiency. This joint project will create the first blockchain solution designed specifically for the EV circular economy.

AMY and Circulor will engage other industrial partners involved in the EV battery lifecycle, including car manufacturers, during the pilot.

As reference to the existing supply chains ethical concerns for battery metals, click the following link to read the CNN article: Carmakers and big tech struggle to keep batteries free from child labor. http://money.cnn.com/2018/05/01/technology/cobalt-congo-child-labor-car-smartphone-batteries/index.html (   http://money.cnn.com/2018/05/01/technology/cobalt-congo-child-labor-car-smartphone-batteries/index.html)

About Circulor Ltd.

Circulor Ltd. (https://www.circulor.com/) is a London (UK) based blockchain start-up focused on materials provenance in the Electric Vehicle supply chain.

Circulor are creating distributed applications to help supply chain participants prove provenance, improve supply chain transparency and reduce counterparty risk exposure. The data pool that will be created in a blockchain ecosystem will eventually allow participants to unlock value well beyond what is currently possible, without compromising commercial confidentiality or violating antitrust/anti-competitive regulations.

The company has been engaging with a range of supply chain participants from car manufacturers to specialists in ethical and sustainable sourcing to prove the utility of blockchain technology and ensure that its solutions can integrate with existing supply chain management solutions.

Circulor is privately held.

About American Manganese Inc.

American Manganese Inc. (https://americanmanganeseinc.com/) is a diversified specialty and critical metal company focused on capitalizing on its patented intellectual property through low cost production or recovery of electrolytic manganese products throughout the world, and recycling of spent electric vehicle lithium ion rechargeable batteries.

Interest in the Companys patented process has adjusted the focus of American Manganese Inc. toward the examination of applying its patented technology for other purposes and materials. American Manganese Inc. aims to capitalize on its patented technology and proprietary know-how to become the industry leader in recycling spent electric vehicle lithium ion batteries and recovering 100% of the cathode metals such as: Lithium-Cobalt, Lithium-Cobalt-Nickel-Manganese, Lithium-Cobalt- Aluminum and Lithium-Manganese (Please see the Companys March 27, 2018 Companys Business Plan (CBP) for further details) (https://americanmanganeseinc.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/AMY_Business_Plan-March2018.pdf).

urn:contentItem:60NN-MFM1-JC11-1027-00000-00American Medical Association Issues Public Comment on FTC Proposed Rule2020-08-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:15ZLexisNexisAmerican Medical Association Issues Public Comment on FTC Proposed RuleTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 -- James L. Madara, executive vice president and CEO of the American Medical Association, Chicago, Illinois, has issued a public comment on the Federal Trade Commission proposed rule entitled "Health Breach Notification". The comment was written on Aug. 20, 2020, and posted on Aug. 21, 2020:

* * *

On behalf of the physician and medical student members of the American Medical Association (AMA), I appreciate the opportunity to submit comments in response to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) request for public comment on its Health Breach Notification (HBN) Rule ("HBN Rule" or "Rule"). The FTC seeks to ensure the Rule has "kept up with changes in the marketplace, technology, and business models," noting that "as consumers turn towards direct-to-consumer technologies for health information services (such as mobile health applications, virtual assistants, and platforms' health tools), more companies may be covered by the FTC's Rule." The AMA greatly appreciates the FTC's recognition of shifts in the technologies patients use to manage their health care and information, particularly following the passage of the 21st Century Cures Act/1 (Cures) and its implementing regulations promulgated by the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology/2 (ONC) and the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services/3 (CMS) earlier this year. As health information is increasingly exchanged outside of the protections of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), the FTC must continue to serve a critical role in preserving and strengthening the privacy and security protections of consumers' health information. The Rule is more important now than ever and we strongly urge the FTC to expand its scope and enforcement.

The first step of any ultimately successful privacy framework, legislative or regulatory, places the patient first. Each entity seeking access to patients' most confidential medical information must pass the stringent test of showing why its professed need should override individuals' most basic right in keeping their own information private. Moreover, citizens deserve a full and open discussion of exactly who wants their private medical information and for what purpose. The AMA's approach to privacy is governed by our Code of Medical Ethics and long-standing policies adopted by our policymaking body, the House of Delegates, which support strong protections for patient privacy. These policies and ethical opinions are designed not only to protect patient privacy, but also to preserve the trust inherent in the patient-physician relationship. Patient trust in the health care system can only be assured when all entities that maintain a patient's health information have an obligation to maintain the confidentiality of that information and when patients truly have autonomy and control over decisions to disclose or retain their personal information. The AMA's recommendations for how to strengthen privacy guardrails and foster greater trust are included below.

The FTC Should Expand the Scope of the HBN Rule Beyond Traditional Personal Health Records (PHRs)

Currently, the Rule's breach notification obligations extend to PHRs, defined as electronic records of identifiable health information that can be drawn from multiple sources and that are managed, shared, and controlled by or primarily for the individual. These obligations stem from Congress' recognition in 2009 that certain entities--namely, vendors of PHRs and PHR-related entities such as those that offer products and services through PHR websites, access information held by PHRs, or send information to PHRs-- collected individuals' health information yet were not subject to HIPAA. Generally speaking, the HBN Rule requires PHRs and PHR-related entities to provide notice to consumers whose unsecured individually identifiable health information has been breached, in addition to providing notice to the FTC and, in some cases, the media. The Rule also requires third-party service vendors to provide notice to PHR vendors and PHR-related entities of breach discoveries.

U.S. health care has gradually shifted over the last 10 years toward digital record-keeping in the professional health care realm--the world of hospitals, health plans, and physician practices. That transition occurred under the umbrella of privacy and security rules rooted in HIPAA, a law which predates most modern online and mobile services, and explicitly excludes health information created or managed by patients themselves or by third-party applications (apps)--the very content the Rule seeks to protect. The rapid growth in the range and volume of digital patient data beyond the confines of the HIPAA framework--and exchanged using technologies and platforms beyond PHRs--merits serious attention. For many patients, the mobile nature and ease of use of third-party apps make them more attractive than traditional PHRs as a way to manage their health records. The AMA expects patients will continue to shift from PHRs to mobile health apps or PHR-health app hybrids going forward. Absent clear guardrails around how entities like app developers use data, public trust will crumble in the face of repeated scandals and undermine the potential for digital health to facilitate an era of more accessible, coordinated, and personalized care.

We learn more each day that personal health information is no longer private. Social media platforms, wearable fitness trackers, and apps allowing patients to download health records from EHRs and manage health conditions all collect data that are not protected by HIPAA. That means these data can be shared for a wide range of purposes, including advertising and marketing. Sharing that health information with data brokers, who can combine it with other consumer information (such as credit score, level of education, and even something as simple as a zip code), creates the perfect recipe for harmful profiling and discrimination./4

Data mining by insurers and employers leads to the creation of health or "risk" scores, which can result in harmful profiling and discrimination. Social media platforms, Internet search engines, wearable fitness trackers, and apps to manage pregnancy and mental health all pool personal data, turning it into a valuable commodity.

Indeed, there is growing awareness of how companies monetize individuals' health and other personal information. A 2019 Morning Consult national survey showed that 94 percent of people feel privacy and security of their medical information is important,/5 while a 2019 study by Rock Health and Stanford's Center for Digital Health shows consumers have become more reticent to share their health data./6

Among health care stakeholders, consumers are most willing to share their health data with physicians, but that sentiment has slipped since 2017, possibly due to spillover from privacy and security breaches in other sectors and general distrust of "big tech."/7

A 2017 Black Book survey reports that:

* 87 percent of patients were unwilling to comprehensively share all of their health information with their physicians;

* 89 percent of consumers who had visited a health care provider in 2016 said they had withheld some information during their visits;

* 81 percent were concerned that information about chronic conditions was being shared without their knowledge; and

* 99 percent were concerned about the sharing of mental health notes./8

In other words, carelessness and lack of transparency in how consumer information is handled and used by technology has likely influenced what information a patient shares with his or her physician. This should serve as a warning to policymakers that consumers take privacy very seriously and that privacy safeguards for consumer-facing technology is critical to preserving patient health and safety./9

Recent events have highlighted not only how critical it is to have clear rules of the road with respect to data use, but also the lost opportunities for progress absent such rules. For example, we are currently experiencing unprecedented reliance on remote care technologies like telehealth to help people avoid leaving their homes during the COVID-19 pandemic. But both patients and clinicians are justified in questioning how platforms will secure and protect the information exchanged during the virtual visits.

Similarly, many private and public efforts are underway to collect, use, and disseminate public health surveillance data to help inform public health officials and policymakers about the spread of the novel coronavirus. These efforts are critically necessary but have thus far provided unsatisfactory answers to questions about how best to handle the data, both during collection and once the pandemic has subsided.

In fact, a poll from the Washington Post and the University of Maryland demonstrate the American public's deep privacy concerns about using tech-enabled COVID-19 tracking and tracing systems that could help limit the pandemic's deadly toll./10

The lack of reliable assurances of how entities will collect, use, and exchange data has fostered reticence from the public to use technologies like public health contact tracing apps.

Finally, HHS' recently finalized interoperability and information blocking rules are poised to drastically impact the exchange, access, and use of electronic medical records. While the AMA wholeheartedly supports the intent of the rules to make it easier for patients to access their electronic health information, the rules lack safeguards to help ensure that patients understand what they are consenting to when they grant permission to an app to access their medical records. The AMA advocated strongly and regularly for HHS to include controls in the final rule to promote transparency on how apps use health information, whom apps share health information with, and how patients could prevent the apps from profiteering off of their data. Unfortunately, HHS failed to take meaningful action in its final rule to promote this type of transparency. As a result, patients may be less willing to share information with physicians for fear that technology companies and data brokers will gain access to and have unrestricted use of their indelible health data.

The AMA believes that mobile health apps and associated devices, trackers, and sensors must better address the privacy and security of patients' medical information. The AMA encourages the mobile app industry and other relevant stakeholders to conduct industry-wide outreach and provide necessary educational materials to patients to promote increased awareness of the varying levels of privacy and security of their information and data afforded by mobile health apps, and how their information and data can potentially be collected and used. The FTC has a valuable opportunity to help foster public trust by strengthening its rules for how apps may use and disclose an individual's health information and should, at a minimum, expand the HBN Rule's coverage to specifically include direct-to-consumer technologies and services such as mobile health apps, virtual assistants, and platforms' health tools (collectively referred to as "entities" in this letter).

The FTC Should Redefine "Unauthorized Access" To Promote Individuals' Understanding of Data Collection and Sharing Practices

Section 13407 of the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Recovery Act),/11 which is the basis for the HBN Rule, and the HBN Rule regulations require PHRs to report the acquisition of unsecured PHR identifiable health information without the authorization of an individual. This definition highlights a pressing question in contemporary discussions around privacy: whether individuals truly understand what information they are authorizing a PHR (or other entity) to acquire, use, and share, simply by clicking "accept" through a series of terms and conditions. Society is increasingly recognizing that a consumer cannot truly, properly authorize the exchange of information without clearly knowing who is receiving the information. The moment a consumer installs an app, it begins searching for that person's data. Even the most vigilant consumer may unwittingly install an app mining for their personal information as nearly every app comes packaged with a range of Software Development Kits (SDKs). As companies have abused SDKs to siphon up personal user data even when they are not supposed to, SDKs have evolved as loopholes in our privacy. Accordingly, we strongly urge the FTC to redefine the term "unauthorized access" as described below to inject greater transparency into the PHR and related-entities ecosystem by incorporating the following recommendations in its HBN Rule.

The FTC should define "unauthorized access" as presumed when entities fail to disclose to individuals how they access, use, process, and disclose their data and for how long data are retained. Specifically, an entity should disclose to individuals exactly what data elements it is collecting and the purpose for their collection. Such information should not be used for a materially different purpose than those disclosed in the notice at the point of collection of such information. For example, an entity that collects location data to provide weather should not use that data for advertising.

Entities should only collect the minimum amount of information needed for a particular purpose, in accordance with regulation and/or federal guidance. For example, a weather app may need general location data (e.g., zip code), but not precise location data (e.g., GPS coordinates). Entities should also make public their data retention policy stipulating which data will be used and for how long. For example, an entity should disclose a policy stating which data elements are retained for operational or regulatory compliance needs. The policy should also explain who is responsible for each category of data and that data are disposed of if no longer needed. Absent this level of specificity, individuals are not truly providing entities with authorized data access.

Furthermore, the FTC should define "unauthorized access" as presumed when an entity fails to disclose to an individual the specific secondary recipients of the individual's data. The Wall Street Journal has reported on how much is at stake when patients share their personal health information with apps. Several apps feed users' personal health information to Facebook even if the individual does not have Facebook installed on his or her phone, or even possess a Facebook account./12

A study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association (JAMA) found that many health apps created to track a user's progress in battling depression or quitting smoking are sharing the personal details they collect about an individual with third parties--like Google and Facebook--without the individual's knowledge or informed consent:

Transmission of data to third-party entities was prevalent, occurring in 33 of 36 top-ranked apps (92%) for depression and smoking cessation, but most apps failed to provide transparent disclosure of such practices. Commonly observed issues included the lack of a written privacy policy, the omission of policy text describing third-party transmission (or for such transmissions to be declared in a nonspecific manner), or a failure to describe the legal jurisdictions that would handle data. In a smaller number of cases, data transmissions were observed that were contrary to the stated privacy policies./13

Social media companies are not the only recipients of this information; apps are also being used as a powerful monitoring tool for employers and payers. Couched in corporate wellness, employers and payers have aggressively pushed to gather more data about their employees' lives than ever before:

Experts worry that companies could use the data to bump up the cost or scale back the coverage of health care benefits, or that women's intimate information could be exposed in data breaches or security risks. Although the data is made anonymous, experts also fear that the companies could identify women based on information relayed in confidence, particularly in workplaces where few women are pregnant at any given time./14

Lastly, the FTC should clarify that "unauthorized access" will be presumed if an entity's privacy policy is not written to promote understanding by those with elementary school levels of reading comprehension. There is an alarming lack of attention on consumer education and patient control over the use of their information once his or her information has been downloaded onto a smartphone. Apps often do not provide patients with clear terms describing how his or her data will be used. An app's terms can be 6,000+ words in length and can shield a developer's activities by permitting a "royalty-free, perpetual, and irrevocable license, throughout the universe" to "utilize and exploit" an individual's deidentified personal information for scientific research and "marketing purposes." The terms may also permit a developer to "sell, lease or lend aggregated Personal Information to third parties."/15

These facts reveal a significant failing in fundamental concepts of equity. Rather than permitting this industry practice to continue, the FTC should require entities to use clearly defined and unambiguous terms in their privacy policies. For example, statements such as, "We may share this data with our partners to improve quality" are vague and should not be permitted. Rather, clear and specific statements such as, "We will share your name, date of birth, and lab results with your employer because you have signed up for their workplace wellness program" should be promoted.

The FTC should Require Entities to Make Their De-Identification Processes and Techniques Publicly Available

The FTC asks whether the definition of "PHR identifiable health information" should be modified in light of technological advances in methods of de-identification and re-identification. Rather than opining on the most appropriate method of de-identification, we first note that there is disagreement among stakeholders over whether information can ever be truly de-identified./16

Additionally, some data historically not considered "personal" or "identifying" (e.g., IP addresses, advertising identifiers from mobile phones) may in fact be both. For example, many apps, particularly free apps, use advertisements to generate revenue. The advertisements collect and share an individual's advertising ID--a string of numbers and letters that identify an individual and keep a log of his or her clicks, searches, purchases, and sometimes geographic location as he or she moves through various apps./17

This information can be "shockingly easy to de-anonymize" and "hundreds of apps collect 'anonymous' real-time location data that needs only the slimmest additional context clues to tie to an individual person."/18

As National Public Radio and ProPublica report, "it isn't hard to understand the appeal of all of this data to insurers:"

Merging information from data brokers with people's clinical and payment records is a no-brainer if you overlook potential patient concerns. Electronic medical records now make it easy for insurers to analyze massive amounts of information and combine it with the personal details scooped up by data brokers...allow[ing] insurers to deny coverage to sick patients./19

Accordingly, we urge the FTC to require greater accountability and transparency from entities claiming that they have de-identified an individual's PHR health information. Specifically, the FTC should revise the definitions section of its HBN Rule to clarify that entities must make their de-identification processes and techniques publicly available.

Decrease the Threshold for Immediate Reporting to the FTC

The FTC notes in its request for comment that the FTC's website lists only two breaches of the HBN Rule, "because the Commission has predominantly received notices about breaches affecting fewer than 500 individuals."/20

The AMA believes that the public may be better served by the HBN Rule if it requires public reporting of breaches affecting fewer than 500 individuals. Strengthening the FTC's enforcement activity in this way would lead to an increased level of transparency and more accurate reporting of those individuals whose information has been improperly disclosed. Accordingly, the AMA urges the FTC to provide additional information to the public regarding the notices it received that impacted fewer than 500 individuals. For example, if the FTC received numerous notices that impacted 300-499 individuals, perhaps the 500+ standard should be revised to require reporting for breaches impacting 300 or more individuals. Again, this emphasis on increased transparency would help to build confidence in the use of technologies such as mobile health apps and encourage the public to regard the FTC as a reliable resource to consult when evaluating which platforms they should entrust with their health data.

In conclusion, the AMA believes that the FTC should continue to serve as the nation's leading consumer protection agency and use its authority to bring enforcement actions against any non-HIPAA covered entity that undermines consumer trust by sharing information, be it health or other pertinent personal data, without consumer knowledge. The AMA believes that the FTC's review of the HBN Rule is significant in light of the dramatic surge in consumer use of cloud-based PHRs and other technologies that assist individuals in managing their health conditions and we appreciate the opportunity to provide these comments.

If you have questions, please contact Laura Hoffman, Assistant Director, Federal Affairs at laura.hoffman@ama-assn.org or 202-789-7414.

Sincerely,

James L. Madara, MD
